{{Cleanup|reason=Uneven, doesn't read like idiomatic English.|date=October 2018}} '''Josef Gunzinger''' was born in [[Welschenrohr]], [[Canton of Solothurn|Solothurn]], [[Switzerland]] on March 23, 1892, and died on May 1, 1970 in [[Heiligenschwendi]]. He was made in 1962 "citizen of honor" of the town of his birth.
Son of Melchior Gunzinger, watchmaker, and Elizabeth Allemann. Married 1920 to Rosalia Allemann, household skills teacher.
Upon his apprentiship as a watchmaker in his father’s workshop, he went to [[La Chaux-de-Fonds]] for a one-year furthering of his skills.
== Business == 1920 he took over the family business and changed the name of the company into Gunzinger Brothers SA. As from 1924, the company started manufacturing watches under the TM [[Technos (watches)|Technos]] that he had previously officially registered.
At its peak in 1970, Technos employed 450 people and exported around the world, particularly in Brazil and Japan. It was by far the biggest employer of the whole valley.
He sold the whole company to [[General Watch Co]]mpany in 1971, a sub-holding of [[ASUAG]].
==Personalities== Josef Gunzinger was a co-founder of the Federation of the Swiss German watch manufacturers in 1924.
He was Welschenrohr Community Councilor (Executive) between 1917 and 1931, and a member of the Canton of Solothurn Grand Council (1921-1925).
He proved to be an entrepreneur doted of a patriarchal fiber with a social touch, although as a politician he was definitely right wing.
Josef Gunzinger is one of the leading figures of the twentieth century flourishing watch industry, whose exemplary-worth values went far beyond Welschenrohr, where he had been for so long the "king of the village".
== References == * U. Fink, ed. Fleissig Hände. Uhrenindustrie in Welschenrohr und im Thal (1880-1980), 2000 -C. Schmid, U. Fink, "Aufstieg und Niedergang der Uhrenindustrie in Welschenrohr" in JbSolG, 73, 2000, 117-177 * http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/f/F30385.php DICTIONNAIRE HISTORIQUE DE LA SUISSE, Author (s): Urban Fink / AN
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gunzinger, Joseph}} [[Category:Watchmakers (people)]] [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1970 deaths]]

{{Infobox football biography | name = Jugurtha Hamroun | image = Jugurta_Hamroun.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = Hamroun as a [[Kardemir Karabükspor|Karabükspor]] player | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|1|27|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bouzeguene]], [[Algeria]] | height = {{convert|1.75|m|abbr=on}} | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] / [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Al Kharaitiyat SC]]
(on loan from [[Al Sadd SC|Al Sadd]]) | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = 2001–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]] | years1 = 2008–2011 | clubs1 = [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp B]] | caps1 = 40 | goals1 = 8 | years2 = 2008–2011 | clubs2 = [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]] | caps2 = 21 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2011–2012 | clubs3 = [[PSFC Chernomorets Burgas|Chernomorets Burgas]] | caps3 = 14 | goals3 = 6 | years4 = 2012–2014 | clubs4 = [[Kardemir Karabükspor|Karabükspor]] | caps4 = 41 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2015 | clubs5 = [[FC Oțelul Galați|Oțelul Galați]] | caps5 = 11 | goals5 = 4 | years6 = 2015–2017 | clubs6 = [[FC Steaua București|FCSB]] | caps6 = 31 | goals6 = 8 | years7 = 2016–2017 | clubs7 = → [[Al Sadd SC|Al Sadd]] (loan) | caps7 = 20 | goals7 = 6 | years8 = 2017– | clubs8 = [[Al Sadd SC|Al Sadd]] | caps8 = 19 | goals8 = 12 | years9 = 2018– | clubs9 = → [[Al Kharaitiyat SC|Al Kharaitiyat]] (loan) | caps9 = 10 | goals9 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Algeria national under-23 football team|Algeria U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = {{date|2018-11-25}} | nationalteam-update = }} '''Jugurtha Hamroun''' ({{lang-ar|يوغرطة حمرون}}; born 27 January 1989) is an [[Algeria]]n professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] or [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Qatar]]i club [[Al Kharaitiyat SC]], on loan from [[Al Sadd SC]]. After starting out at [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]] in France, he went on to compete professionally in Bulgaria, Turkey, Romania and Qatar. Hamroun represented [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] at [[Algeria national under-23 football team|under-23 level]], making his debut in November 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.lebuteur.com/pdf-lebuteur/voir-journal/1096|title=Les Olympiques avertissent le Senegal|trans-title=Olympians caution Senegal|publisher=Le Buteur|language=French|page=6|date=15 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116233618/http://www.lebuteur.com/pdf-lebuteur/voir-journal/1096|archivedate=16 November 2011|df=}} ==Early life== Hamroun was born in the town of [[Bouzeguene]] in the [[Tizi Ouzou Province]]. At age 5, he moved with his family to [[France]], where they settled in [[Neuilly-sur-Marne]] in the eastern suburbs of [[Paris]].[http://www.dzfoot.com/article-1530.php Découverte: Interview Jugurtha Hamroun (Discovery: Jugurtha Hamround interview)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721011412/http://www.dzfoot.com/article-1530.php|date=21 July 2009}}; at DZFoot (in French) ==Club career== ===Guingamp=== At age 12, Hamroun joined the youth ranks of French club [[En Avant de Guingamp]]. On 8 April 2008, he signed his first professional contract, for a period of three years, and on 29 August of that year he made his [[Ligue 2]] debut, coming as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Cédric Liabeuf]] in the 83rd minute of a 1–1 home draw against [[CS Sedan Ardennes]]. During his three-year spell at the ''[[Stade du Roudourou]]'', Hamroun alternated between the first team and the reserves, going on to appear in 26 competitive games for the former, including twice in the [[2009–10 UEFA Europa League]].{{cite news|url=http://fr.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000036/match=2000720/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Hambourg déroule au Roudourou|trans-title=Hambourg steamrolls at Roudourou|publisher=UEFA.com|language=French|date=20 August 2009|accessdate=9 March 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://fr.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000036/match=2000757/postmatch/report/index.html|title=En Avant Hambourg!|publisher=UEFA.com|language=French|date=27 August 2009|accessdate=9 March 2016}} ===Chernomorets Burgas=== On 26 July 2011, Hamroun signed a three-year deal with [[Bulgaria]]n team [[PSFC Chernomorets Burgas]], joining on a [[Free transfer (association football)|free transfer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.novsport.com/news153325_1062.html|title=Черноморец подписва с Жужу|trans-title=Chernomorets signed with Zhouzhou|publisher=Novsport|language=Bulgarian|date=July 2011|accessdate=26 July 2011}} He scored in his [[Bulgarian A Football Group|A PFG]] debut, helping to a 2–0 home win over [[PFC Lokomotiv Plovdiv]] on 20 August. ===Kardemir Karabükspor=== On 18 January 2012, however, Hamroun moved clubs and countries again, being sold to [[Kardemir Karabükspor]] in the Turkish [[Süper Lig]] for a reported fee of [[Euro|€]]600,000. He played his first match three days later, starting and featuring 70 minutes in the 2–1 home success over [[Trabzonspor]]. In [[2012–13 Süper Lig|his first full season]], Hamroun contributed with 20 scoreless appearances as the side narrowly avoided relegation after ranking 15th. ===Oțelul Galați=== In January 2015, after being a [[free agent]] since the summer, Hamroun signed a six-month contract with Romania's [[FC Oțelul Galați]], who were in the midst of a financial crisis. The second of his [[Liga I]] goals came on 19 April in a 2–1 win at [[2014–15 Liga I|eventual champions]] [[FC Steaua București]],{{cite news|url=http://www.sportnews.ro/reincarnare-pe-arena-nationala-steaua-batuta-de-un-jucator-dinaintea-erei-noastre-povestea-necunoscuta-a-eroului-otelului-algerianul-jughurta-hamroun-sunt-mandru-de-numele-meu-de-razboi-195732.html|title=REÎNCARNARE! Steaua, bătută de un jucător "dinaintea erei noastre"!|trans-title=REINCARNATION! Steaua, defeated by a player "before our era"!|publisher=Sport News|language=Romanian|date=20 April 2015|accessdate=30 May 2015}} but his team was not able to eventually stave off relegation. ===FCSB=== After Oțelul's relegation into [[Liga II]], Hamroun refused to extend his contract and, as it was due to expire, fellow league side [[FC Petrolul Ploiești]] showed interest in signing the player.{{cite news|url=http://www.digisport.ro/Sport/FOTBAL/Competitii/Liga+1/VIDEO+Jugurtha+Hamroun+va+ramane+in+Liga+1+|title=Jugurtha Hamroun va rămâne în Liga 1, după ce și-a dat acordul să joace pentru Petrolul sezonul viitor|trans-title=Jugurtha Hamroun will stay in Liga 1, after agreeing to play for Petrolul next season|publisher=[[DigiSport]]|language=Romanian|date=30 May 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}} On 29 June 2015, he was announced as player of [[Giresunspor]] on their official website, but the deal eventually fell through due to the club being in debt and not allowed to make any transfers;{{cite news|url=http://www.prosport.ro/fotbal-intern/liga-1/rasturnare-de-situatie-federatia-s-a-implicat-iar-steaua-poate-realiza-transferul-mult-visat-radoi-primeste-magician-de-liga-14567737|title=Răsturnare de situaţie! Federaţia s-a implicat, iar Steaua poate realiza transferul mult visat: Rădoi primeşte "magician" de Ligă|trans-title=Turnaround! The Federation got involved, and Steaua can accomplish their dream transfer: Rădoi receives a "magician"|publisher=[[ProSport]]|language=Romanian|date=9 July 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}} in July, he joined FCSB on a three-year deal,{{cite news|url=http://www.steauafc.com/ro/articol/transfer_hamroun/|title=Bine ai venit, Jugurtha Hamroun!|trans-title=Welcome, Jugurtha Hamroun!|publisher=Steaua București|language=Romanian|date=9 July 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}} making his debut on the 14th against [[AS Trenčín]] in the first leg of the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|second qualifying round]] for the [[UEFA Champions League]] and scoring the second goal of the 2–0 away win.{{cite news|url=http://www.digisport.ro/Sport/FOTBAL/Competitii/Champions+League/VIDEO+Hamroun+a+avut+un+debut+de+vis+la+Steaua+E+una+dintre+cele|title=Hamroun a avut un debut de vis la Steaua: "E una dintre cele mai fericite zile din viaţa mea"|trans-title=Hamroun had a dream debut at Steaua: "It's one of the happiest days of my life"|publisher=DigiSport|language=Romanian|date=15 July 2015|accessdate=15 July 2015}} ==International career== On 22 December 2009, Hamroun was called up to the [[Algeria national under-23 football team|Algerian under-23 national team]] by head coach [[Abdelhak Bencheikha]], for a week-long training camp in [[Algiers]].[http://www.dzfoot.com/news-5493/en-espoirs-27-joueurs-convoques/ EN Espoirs: 27 joueurs convoqués (NT Under-21: 27 players called)]; at DZFoot (in French) In October 2011, after scoring four goals in eight games in the [[2011–12 A PFG|Bulgarian League]], he was recalled by new manager [[Azzedine Aït Djoudi]] after an almost two-year absence.[http://www.dzfoot.com/news-10018/en-u23-mehdi-abeid-et-jugurtha-hamroun-en-renfort/ EN U23: Mehdi Abeid et Jugurtha Hamroun en renfort (NT Under-23: Mehdi Abeid and Jugurtha Hamroun are additions)]; DZFoot, 5 October 2011 (in French) On 15 November 2011, Hamroun made his debut for the under-23s, as a second-half substitute in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against [[South Africa national under-23 football team|South Africa]]. The following day, he was selected for the squad [[2011 CAF U-23 Championship|due to appear]] at the [[Africa U-23 Cup of Nations]] in [[Morocco]].[http://www.dzfoot.com/news-10307/en-u23-les-21-joueurs-selectionnes/ EN U23: Les 21 joueurs sélectionnés (NT Under-23: The 21 selected players)]; DZFoot, 16 November 2011 (in French) ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 21 April 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/jugurtha-hamroun/59344/|title=J. Hamroun|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=6 April 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.joueurs.jugurtha.hamroun.44132.fr.html|title=Jugurtha {{Other people}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Katherine Harris |image = Katherine Harris (R–FL).jpg |state = [[Florida]] |district = {{ushr|FL|13|13th}} |term_start = January 3, 2003 |term_end = January 3, 2007 |predecessor = [[Dan Miller (Florida politician)|Dan Miller]] |successor = [[Vern Buchanan]] |office1 = 23rd [[Secretary of State of Florida]] |governor1 = [[Jeb Bush]] |term_start1 = January 5, 1999 |term_end1 = August 2, 2002 |predecessor1 = [[Sandra Mortham]] |successor1 = [[James C. Smith|James Smith]] |state_senate2 = Florida |district2 = 24th |term_start2 = 1994 |term_end2 = 1998 |predecessor2 = [[Jim Boczar]] |successor2 = [[Lisa Carlton]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|4|5}} |birth_place = [[Key West, Florida|Key West]], [[Florida]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Anders Ebbeson (1996–2013)
Richard Ware (2017–present) |education = [[Agnes Scott College]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Harvard University]] ([[Master of Public Administration|MPA]]) }} '''Katherine Harris''' (born April 5, 1957) is an American politician, elected in 1998 as [[Secretary of State of Florida]] and in 2002 to the [[United States House of Representatives]] from Florida. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], Harris won the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 2002|2002 election]] to represent [[Florida's 13th congressional district]], serving for two terms, from 2003 to 2007. Harris lost her campaign in 2006 for a [[United States Senate]] seat from Florida. In 1994, Harris was noted for the most expensive campaign for the Florida Senate to date, winning her seat that year in her entry into electoral politics. In the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 presidential election]], Harris gained national attention for her role in the [[Florida election recount]], certifying [[George W. Bush]]'s narrow victory (537 votes) over [[Al Gore]] and awarding him the Florida electors, which gained him the national election. ==Background and personal life== Harris was born in [[Key West, Florida]] to one of the state's wealthiest and most politically influential families.[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2000/11/15/politics/main249787.shtml "The Woman in Charge"]. [[CBS News]]. November 15, 2000. She is the daughter of Harriet (Griffin) and George W. Harris, Jr., who owned Citrus and Chemical Bank in [[Lakeland, Florida]].Follick, Joe (July 22, 2001). "Tracks in Florida's Sand", ''[[Tampa Tribune]]''.[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2003-08-17/news/0308170039_1_hill-griffin-griffin-iii-ben-hill], ''Orlando Sentinel,'' 17 August 2003 Her maternal grandfather was [[Ben Hill Griffin, Jr.]], a successful businessman in the [[citrus]] and cattle industries and a powerful figure in the state legislature. Shortly before his death in 1990, he was ranked as the 261st richest American on the [[Forbes 400]] list.Narvaez, Alfonso A. (March 2, 1990). [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/03/02/obituaries/ben-hill-griffin-jr-79-is-dead-leader-in-florida-citrus-industry.html "Ben Hill Griffin Jr., 79, is Dead; Leader in Florida Citrus Industry"], ''The New York Times''. Section A, Page 18, Column 4. [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] at the [[University of Florida]] is named for him.[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-550501.html Milbank, Dana; Becker, Jo (November 14, 2000). "Controversy swirls around Harris"], ''Washington Post'' Harris' extended family has been active in [[Christian evangelism]]. Her grandfather was a Christian missionary in Africa, while her aunt and uncle were missionaries in India. They now head the Arab World Missions. Harris studied under Dr. [[Francis Schaeffer]] at a L'Abri Fellowship International center. Harris attended Greystone, an all-girls Christian camp at [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. She has said her faith is "the most important thing in my life." Harris was reared in the [[Presbyterian Church in America]], but as an adult, she has criticized the [[Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.)]] for being "more liberal." She attends [[Calvary Chapel]], a non-denominational charismatic church in [[Sarasota, Florida]]. Harris married Swedish businessman Sven Anders Axel Ebbeson in 1996 and has one stepdaughter, Louise. Sven Ebbeson committed [[suicide]] in November 2013.{{cite news|last=Wallace|first=Jeremy|title=Husband of Katherine Harris commits suicide, police say|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20131119/ARTICLE/131119595?p=all|work=Herald Tribune |date=November 19, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508214808/http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20131119/ARTICLE/131119595?p=all |archivedate=May 8, 2014 |deadurl=no}} ==Education and career== Harris graduated from [[Bartow High School]] in [[Bartow, Florida]], in 1975. She attended the [[European University of Madrid|University of Madrid]] in 1978. Harris received a Bachelor of Arts degree in history from [[Agnes Scott College]] in [[Decatur, Georgia]], in 1979. She studied under Christian [[Theology|theologian]] [[Francis Schaeffer]] at the [[L'Abri|L'Abri community]] in [[Ollon|Huemoz]], Switzerland, near [[Lausanne]]. While in college she worked as an intern for U.S. Representative [[Andy Ireland]]. Before entering politics, Harris worked as a marketing executive at [[IBM]] and a vice president of a commercial real estate firm.[http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/1617/katherine-harris "Katherine Harris' Biography"]. ''[[Project Vote Smart]]''. Retrieved April 30, 2006. Harris earned a [[Master of Public Administration|M.P.A.]] from [[Harvard University]]'s [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]] in 1996.{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/15518339/ns/politics/t/katherine-harris/ |title=Profile: Katherine Harris |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508220746/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/15518339/ns/politics/t/katherine-harris/ |archivedate=May 8, 2014|date=2012| website=NBCNews.com |publisher=National Journal Group Inc |deadurl=no}} ==Political career== Harris joined the Republican Party. She ran for the [[Florida Senate]] in 1994 in one of the most expensive state races in Florida history to date. Harris's political career was guided by [[Dan Berger (politics)|Dan Berger]], Adam Goodman, and Benjamin McKay, along with her campaign manager, David Lapides. ===Florida Senate and Riscorp=== Harris played a prominent role in introducing William Griffin (with whom she had a close personal relationship), the CEO of Riscorp, to various Florida legislators. In the 1994 state senate election, [[Sarasota]]-based Riscorp, Inc. made illegal contributions totaling $400,000 to dozens of political candidates and committees,Rado, Diane (August 25, 1998). [http://www.sptimes.com/State/82598/Harris_backed_bill_ai.html "Harris backed bill aiding Riscorp"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020808142202/http://www.sptimes.com/State/82598/Harris_backed_bill_ai.html |date=August 8, 2002 }}, ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]''. including $20,600 to the Harris campaign.[http://www.nndb.com/people/067/000038950/ "Katherine Harris"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060705081225/http://www.nndb.com/people/067/000038950/ |date=July 5, 2006 }}. [[NNDB]]. Retrieved April 30, 2006. Two years later, in 1996, Harris sponsored a bill "to block Riscorp competitors from getting a greater share of Florida [[workers' compensation]] market, [and] also pushed a proposal that would hurt a particular competitor." This issue later emerged during her campaign for Florida Secretary of State in 1998. William Griffin eventually pleaded guilty to illegal campaign donations, among allegations of other serious wrongdoing at Riscorp, and served prison time in 1998. The election of Republican [[Jeb Bush]] as governor of Florida is considered to have been a major factor in stopping further state investigation into the Riscorp scandal. According to a ''Sun-Herald'' column from June 2005, "Harris denied any knowledge of the scheme, was never charged with any crime and was cleared of wrongdoing by a state investigator."{{cite news |author=Gleason, Brian |date=June 28, 2005 |url=http://www.sun-herald.com/NewsArchive2/062805/cl5.htm?date=062805&story=cl5.htm |title=Will Harris get dragged into finance scandal? |work=Sun and Weekly Herald |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070101043055/http://www.sun-herald.com/NewsArchive2/062805/cl5.htm?date=062805&story=cl5.htm |archivedate=January 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} ===Secretary of State=== Harris was elected Florida Secretary of State in 1998. She defeated then-incumbent [[Sandra Mortham]] in the Republican primary and won the general election against Democratic candidate, Karen Gievers, an attorney from Miami.George, Robert (November 4, 1998). [http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-11-04/news/9811040061_1_katherine-harris-campaign-money-illegal-campaign "Last-minute Donations Boost Harris"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016055208/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1998-11-04/news/9811040061_1_katherine-harris-campaign-money-illegal-campaign|date=October 16, 2013}}. ''[[Florida Sun-Sentinel]]''. Retrieved December 30, 2011.[http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0877742.html "Katherine Harris"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060528010632/http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0877742.html |date=May 28, 2006 }}. ''[[infoplease]]''. Retrieved April 30, 2006. ====International travel==== During her first 22 months in office, Harris spent more than $106,000 for travel, more than the [[Governor of Florida|governor]] or any other cabinet officer. She visited eight countries including Iran, India, and the Netherlands on ten foreign trips. In early 2001, Florida Senate leaders eliminated the $3.4 million that Harris had budgeted for international relations for the year, assigning it instead to ''Enterprise Florida'', the state's economic development agency. However, Florida House Leader [[Tom Feeney]] said that he disagreed with the Senate and believed that Harris was an able advocate to foreign countries. After the House refused to agree with the proposed budget action, the Senate agreed to restore the money; however, it insisted on a review committee, appointed by Senate President John McKay, Feeney, and Governor [[Jeb Bush]], to evaluate all of Harris' expenditures on international affairs since July 1, 1999, and produce a report.Morgan, Lucy (July 31, 2001). [http://www.sptimes.com/News/073101/news_pf/State/Millions_for_Harris__.shtml "Millions for Harris's trips under review"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104070927/http://www.sptimes.com/News/073101/news_pf/State/Millions_for_Harris__.shtml |date=January 4, 2007 }}, ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]''. ====2000 U.S. presidential election==== {{main|United States presidential election in Florida, 2000}} As Secretary of State for the State of Florida (and co-chair of George W. Bush's election efforts in Florida), Harris was a central figure in the [[2000 US presidential election]] in Florida. The election between [[Al Gore]] and [[George W. Bush]] was so close in Florida, separated by 537 votes, that a recount of the votes was called for. After several recounts were inconclusive and the laws governing recounts were unclear, Harris halted the recounting process. She certified that the [[U.S. Republican Party|Republican]] candidate, Texas Governor [[George W. Bush]], had defeated the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate, Vice President [[Al Gore]], in the popular vote of Florida and thus certified the Republican slate of [[United States Electoral College|electors]]. This victory in Florida allowed Bush to win the election. Her ruling was upheld in the state circuit court, but was subsequently overturned on appeal by the Florida Supreme Court. The Florida Supreme Court decision was reversed by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] in ''[[Bush v. Gore]]''. (2000) In a [[per curiam decision]], by a 7-2 vote, the Court in ''Bush v. Gore'' held that the [[Florida Supreme Court]]'s method for recounting ballots was a violation of the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]]. By a 5–4 vote, the US Supreme Court held that no alternative method for a recount could be established within the time limits set by the State of Florida. The decision allowed Harris' previous certification of Bush as the winner of Florida's electoral votes to stand. Florida's 25 electoral votes gave Bush, the Republican candidate, 271 electoral votes, defeating Gore, who ended up with 266 electoral votes (with one D.C. elector abstaining). Harris later published ''Center of the Storm,'' her memoir of the 2000 election controversy. ==United States Congresswoman== In 2002, Harris ran against [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]] Attorney [[Jan Schneider]] for the congressional district vacated by retiring Republican Rep. [[Dan Miller (Florida politician)|Dan Miller]], winning by 10 percentage points in this solidly Republican district, a victory helped with one of the biggest first term campaign fund raising efforts in the history of this district and substantial support from the Bush family. Harris considered running for the seat of retiring Senator [[Bob Graham]] in 2004 but was reportedly dissuaded by the Bush White House to allow [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development|Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]] [[Mel Martinez]] to run instead. Martinez went on to narrowly beat challenger [[Betty Castor]]. Harris ran for re-election to her House seat in 2004; she was re-elected with a margin almost identical to her first win.{{cite web |url=http://srqelections.com/results/gen2004sum.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817092336/http://srqelections.com/results/gen2004sum.htm |title=Official General Election, Sarasota County, November 2, 2004 |publisher= Sarasota County Supervisor of Elections Office |date=November 4, 2004 |archivedate=August 17, 2008 |deadurl=yes}} In a 2004 speech in [[Venice, Florida]], Harris claimed that a "Middle Eastern" man was arrested for attempting to blow up the power grid in [[Carmel, Indiana]];Grace, Francie (August 5, 2004). [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/08/05/politics/main634122.shtml "Katherine Harris 'Oops' On Terror"]. ''[[CBS News]]''. Carmel Mayor James Brainard and a spokesman for Indiana Gov. [[Joe Kernan (politician)|Joe Kernan]] said they had no knowledge of such a plot. Brainard said he had never spoken to Harris.{{cite news|author=Hackett, David |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?p=all&AID=/20040804/NEWS/408040633/1060 |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |title=Harris' words surprise officials |date=August 4, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509221547/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?p=all&AID=%2F20040804%2FNEWS%2F408040633%2F1060 |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} During a 2004 campaign stop in Sarasota, a local resident, Barry Seltzer, "tr[ied] to 'intimidate' a group of Harris supporters" by menacing Harris and her supporters with his automobile. Witnesses described Seltzer as having swerved off the road and onto the sidewalk, directing it at Harris and her supporters. Nobody was injured in the incident. Seltzer, who claimed he was "exercising [his] political expression," was eventually arrested and charged with assault with a deadly weapon.[http://www.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/10/27/fl.13.harris.attack "Man accused of trying to run down Rep. Katherine Harris"]. ''[[CNN]]''. October 27, 2004. ==MZM incident== In 2005 and 2006, a major corporate campaign donor to Harris, Mitchell Wade (founder of [[defense contractor]] [[MZM Scandal|MZM]]), was implicated in several [[Cunningham scandal|bribery scandals]]. Wade had bundled together and donated to Harris's campaign $32,000 in contributions from his employees at MZM, Inc., then reimbursed those employees for the contributions.{{cite news|title=Harris didn't tell all about donations |date=February 26, 2006 |author=Wallace, Jeremy |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060226/NEWS/602260310&p=all |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510170913/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060226%2FNEWS%2F602260310&p=all |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} Regarding this issue, [[U.S. Attorney]] Kenneth Wainstein said that Harris did not appear to know the donations were obtained illegally. Harris has maintained she had no personal knowledge that her campaign was given illegal contributions. Wade acknowledged that the donations to the Harris campaign were illegal and were part of an attempt to influence Harris to MZM's benefit.{{cite news|author=Wallace, Jeremy |date=February 26, 2006 |title='Straw' Breaking Harris's Back |url=http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060226/NEWS/602260371/1134 |work=The Ledger |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927191707/http://www.theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060226%2FNEWS%2F602260371%2F1134 |archivedate=September 27, 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} Documents filed with Wade's plea say that he took Harris to dinner in March 2005, a year after the illegal contributions, where they discussed the possibility of another fundraiser and the possibility of getting funding for a Navy [[counterintelligence]] program placed in Harris's district.{{cite news | title=Contractor Pleads Guilty to Corruption|author=Babcock, Charles R. |work=The Washington Post | date=February 25, 2006 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/24/AR2006022401737.html}} Harris sent a letter on April 26, 2005, to defense appropriations subcommittee Chairman [[Bill Young|C. W. Bill Young]], in which Harris sought $10 million for a Navy project backed by Wade. In the letter, Harris emphasized the importance of the project, asking that it be added to her list of five priorities and identifying it as her new No. 3. Harris later released the April 26, 2005, letter for legal scrutiny, but neither she nor Young would turn over the request form (RFP) used for the proposal.{{cite news | title=Harris Shuns Spending Requests | url=http://www.tbo.com/news/metro/MGB5MTE1CKE.html | author=Epstein, Keith | publisher=Tampa Tribune |date=March 3, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060628123717/http://www.tbo.com/news/metro/MGB5MTE1CKE.html |archivedate = June 28, 2006|deadurl=yes}} ''[[CQPolitics]]'' noted "Harris's former political strategist, [[Ed Rollins]], spoke on the record about the dinner and detailed a meal that cost $2,800, far in excess of the $50 limit on gifts that members of Congress are allowed to accept" at the Washington restaurant Citronelle.{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB114722702872148541 |title=Katherine Harris Battles Old Friends For Florida's Keys |date=May 10, 2006 |author=McKinnon, John D. |work=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=May 9, 2014}} Wade and Harris discussed MZM's desire for a $10 million appropriation, and Wade offered to host a fundraiser for Harris's 2006 Senate campaign. Regarding the MZM contributions, the ''Sentinel'' article goes on to say "The [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] has said Wade, who personally handed many of the checks to Harris, did not tell Harris the contributions were illegal". Regarding the expensive meal, the article quotes Harris as saying that she personally had only a "beverage and appetizer" worth less than "$100". Rollins said that he had conducted a thorough internal investigation into Harris's ties to MZM in hopes of finding conclusive proof of her innocence; but when he could not, he and other advisers, including her lawyer, urged her to drop her candidacy rather than risk federal corruption charges. Although he did not believe Harris intentionally broke any laws, "her story kept changing. Our great concern was that you get into trouble when you don't tell the same story twice ... Maybe you don't think you did anything wrong, but then maybe you start getting questioned about it and so forth, and you may [[perjury|perjure]] yourself. ... Unlike Cunningham, I don't think she set out to violate the law, but I think she was very careless. She heard whatever she wanted to hear, but we could find no evidence whatsoever that this was a project going into her district."{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/05/21/State/Briber_paid_for_2nd_m.shtml |title=Briber paid for 2nd meal for Harris|work=St. Petersburg Times |date=May 21, 2006 |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |author=Smith, Adam C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604213129/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/05/21/State/Briber_paid_for_2nd_m.shtml |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |deadurl=no}} Although Rollins recalled discussing the $2,800 meal with Harris, Harris told the ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' on April 19, 2006, that the cost of the meal was "news to me", and that her campaign had since "reimbursed" the restaurant for the cost of the meal. According to the reporter, when questioned as to why she would reimburse the restaurant for a meal that had been paid for by MZM, Harris abruptly terminated the interview, and her spokesman later called and requested unsuccessfully that the story not be printed. The next day, Harris's campaign issued a statement that she had believed her campaign had reimbursed the restaurant, and that she had donated $100 "which will more than adequately compensate for the cost of my beverage and appetizer".{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-04-21/news/HARRISDINNER_1_harris-dinner-wade |title=Contractor picked up dinner tab for Harris |date=April 21, 2006 |author=Stratton, Jim |work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140509225636/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-04-21/news/HARRISDINNER_1_harris-dinner-wade |archivedate=May 9, 2014 |deadurl=no}} Harris also asserted that most of the cost of the meal was from Wade ordering several unopened bottles of wine to take home, although the management of the restaurant denies ever allowing anyone to take unopened bottles of wine off the premises, saying "Why would we jeopardize our liquor license for the sake of selling a couple bottles of wine?" In the weeks following the expensive meal, former senior Harris staffers claimed that "they initially rejected a defense contractor's $10 million appropriation request last year but reversed course after being instructed by Harris to approve it."{{cite news | title=Contractor's deal was Harris priority, former staffers say |author=Stratton, Jim | work=Orlando Sentinel |date=May 4, 2006 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-05-04/news/MHARRISREQUEST0_1_harris-staff-members-wade |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110810204754/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-05-04/news/MHARRISREQUEST0_1_harris-staff-members-wade|archivedate=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=no}} In May 2006, Harris's campaign spokesman Christopher Ingram acknowledged that she had also had a previous dinner with Wade in the same restaurant in March 2004, when the $32,000 in illegal donations had been given to her campaign. Ingram told the press that he did not know how much that meal cost, but that a charitable donation of an unknown amount had been given to a charity whose name he did not know, equivalent to her share of the meal. "She takes responsibility for the oversight that there was no reimbursement," he said. Mona Tate Yost, an aide to Harris, left to work for MZM during the time Wade was pressing Harris to secure federal funding (April or May 2005).{{cite news|title=Ex-Harris Aide Linked to Convicted Contractor |author=Reiss, Cory |author2=Wallace, Jeremy |work=The Ledger |date=March 1, 2006 |url=http://theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060301/NEWS/603010336/1004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930154838/http://theledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060301%2FNEWS%2F603010336%2F1004 |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} On July 17, 2006, Ed Rollins confirmed that Justice Department lawyers and FBI agents had recently questioned her about the $32,000 in donations. Rollins noted: "I assume more [interviews] will be coming, though. They were very serious."{{cite news | title=Feds query ex-adviser on Harris |author=Stratton, Jim | work=Orlando Sentinel |date=July 18, 2006 |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-07-18/news/HARRIS18_1_harris-wade-rollins |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810204803/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-07-18/news/HARRIS18_1_harris-wade-rollins |archivedate=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=no}} On September 7, 2006, Federal investigators questioned Jim Dornan, who quit as Harris's campaign manager the previous November.Kumar, Anita (September 9, 2006). [http://www.sptimes.com/2006/09/09/State/Feds_interview_Harris.shtml "Feds interview Harris's ex-campaign manager"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630142810/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/09/09/State/Feds_interview_Harris.shtml |date=June 30, 2007 }}. ''St. Petersburg Times''. ==2006 Senate race== {{main|Florida United States Senate election, 2006}} ===Overview=== On June 7, 2005, with support from her new campaign advisors of [[Ed Rollins]] and Jim Dornan, Harris announced her candidacy for the 2006 Florida United States Senate election, challenging [[Democratic Party (US)|Democratic]] [[incumbent]] [[Bill Nelson]]. Both lackluster fundraising relative to Nelson and [[#Involvement in the MZM scandal|controversy over campaign contributions from MZM]] caused Harris to fall far behind in all polls by May 2006.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Late in the primary race, Republican contender Will McBride polled 31 points behind Nelson in a hypothetical election against him, while Harris polled 33 points behind Nelson in the same poll. Harris was still popular among Republican voters and won the September 5 primary over McBride and two other challengers with approximately 50% of the total vote.{{cite news |url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/florida/release-detail?ReleaseId=934 |title=Nelson Has 2 -1 Lead Over Harris, Any GOP Contender |publisher=[[Quinnipiac University]] |date=June 30, 2006 |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510165332/http://www.quinnipiac.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/florida/release-detail?ReleaseId=934 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} Despite Harris's support of many Republican causes and her previous statewide victories, some party leaders expressed doubt about her statewide appeal: * In May 2006, Florida Governor [[Jeb Bush]] questioned Harris's ability to win the general election and encouraged others to challenge her in the primary.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060508/BREAKING/60508009&p=all |title=Bush says Harris can't win |work=Herald Tribune |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=May 8, 2006 |author=Kaczor, Bill |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510170810/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060508%2FBREAKING%2F60508009&p=all |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news | title= Republican declines to run against Harris | work=Washington Post |agency=Associated Press |date=May 11, 2006 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/05/10/AR2006051000891_pf.html |author=Royse, David }} * [[Karl Rove]] expressed doubts about her statewide appeal. * National Republicans openly criticized her campaign and tried to convince other GOP candidates to challenge Harris in the primary.{{cite news |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Common-Cause-Seeks-Justice-Probe-of-Harris/id-2843658a166bbb7a5fc56fffa9bec499 |date=May 1, 2006 |title=Common Cause Seeks Justice Probe of Harris|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510180621/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Common-Cause-Seeks-Justice-Probe-of-Harris/id-2843658a166bbb7a5fc56fffa9bec499 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} * Florida state House of Representatives Speaker [[Allan Bense]] declined the candidacy on May 11 despite public courting by many leaders including Governor Bush. * Conservative pundit and former Republican Congressman [[Joe Scarborough]] was also unsuccessfully recruited to enter the race. Departing Harris aides claim that Harris called potential Scarborough supporters and raised the death of an aide in order to prevent his entry into the race.{{cite news |author=Caputo, Marc |title=Story of 'Joe's dead intern' began Harris's slide, insiders say |work=[[Miami Herald]] |date=July 14, 2006 |url=http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/15034557.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719031725/http://www.miami.com/mld/miamiherald/15034557.htm |archivedate=July 19, 2006 |deadurl=yes}} Scarborough later told Nelson that drawing Harris as an opponent in the race made him "the luckiest man in Washington".Kumar, Anita (May 11, 2006). [http://www.sptimes.com/2006/05/11/State/GOP_can_t_elude_Harri.shtml "GOP can't elude Harris vs. Nelson"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523234134/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/05/11/State/GOP_can_t_elude_Harri.shtml |date=May 23, 2011 }}. [[St. Petersburg Times]]. By late July 2006, Harris had gone through three campaign managers and her campaign was floundering. At that time, it was disclosed that state Republican Party leaders had told Harris they would not support her because she could not win in the general election. Financial problems plagued Harris' Senate campaign from the start. During the primary, it was clear that the incumbent Senator Nelson had a substantial financial advantage. On the March 15, 2006, edition of [[Fox News Channel]]'s ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]'', Harris pledged to spend $10 million of her own money, which she said was all of her inheritance, on her campaign. She also stated that her run was dedicated to the memory of her father.Wallace, Jeremy (March 16, 2006). [http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060316/NEWS/603160716&p=all "Harris in to win with her own $10M"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510191112/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060316%2FNEWS%2F603160716&p=all|date=May 10, 2014}}. ''[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]''. Despite her promise, the $10 million never materialized. Reports surfaced that Harris would not actually receive the inheritance from her father, who instead left his entire estate to her mother. She donated $3 million to her campaign, but later took back $100,000, fueling speculation that she would be unable to donate the promised amount.Kumar, Anita (August 26, 2006). [http://www.sptimes.com/2006/08/26/State/Harris_campaign_await.shtml "Harris campaign awaits her cash"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307191719/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/08/26/State/Harris_campaign_await.shtml |date=March 7, 2007 }}. ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]''. In October, Harris announced that she was trying to sell her house in Washington to raise money for her campaign,Schatz, Amy (October 18, 2006). [https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2006/10/18/harris-vows-to-sell-home-to-raise-cash-for-campaign/ "Harris Vows to Sell Home to Raise Cash for Campaign"]. "Washington Wire," ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. but the home was not publicly listed for sale and no sale was ever announced.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Nelson defeated Harris by more than one million votes. Harris received less than 39% of the vote. ====Staff resignations==== In late February 2006, in the midst of revelations surrounding Mitchell Wade's illegal contributions, Harris's campaign finance director and her campaign treasurer both resigned.{{cite news|title=Setback for Harris campaign is latest of several rough spots |author=Follick, Joe |publisher=Herald Tribune |date=February 26, 2006 |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060226/NEWS/602260714&p=all |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510193734/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060226%2FNEWS%2F602260714&p=all |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} On April 1, 2006 Harris's top campaign advisor, pollster and campaign manager all resigned with a half-dozen other staffers. Republican pollster and consultant David Johnson said, "I've never seen staffers go like this. It's just imploding."Weisenmiller, Mark (September 22, 2006). [http://www.albionmonitor.com/0609a/copyright/harrisflounders.html "Katharine Harris of La Mancha"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306214443/http://www.albionmonitor.com/0609a/copyright/harrisflounders.html |date=March 6, 2012 }}. ''Albion Monitor''. [[Inter Press Service]]. In early April 2006, Harris told the ''[[Tampa Tribune]]'' that some of her ex-campaign staffers and the national Republican party were deliberately sabotaging her campaign by "putting knives in her back" and had warned her that if she did not back out of the campaign, she would get an "April surprise".{{cite news |url=http://www.tampatrib.com/MGBEOW9PLLE.html |title=Questions Dog Harris Behavior |author=March, William |author2=Epstein, Keith |work=Tampa Tribune |date=April 4, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060621184233/http://www.tampatrib.com/MGBEOW9PLLE.html |archivedate=June 21, 2006 |deadurl=no}} Former campaign staffer Ed Rollins said "They were all good professionals ... There was no backstabbing. It's insulting that she would even say that. If she wants to know what went wrong with the campaign, maybe she needs to take a good look in the mirror."{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?Date=20060404&Category=NEWS&ArtNo=604040332&S&p=all |date=April 4, 2006 |author=Wallace, Jeremy |title=Harris campaign 'bleeding' continues |work=Herald Tribune |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510201832/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?Date=20060404&Category=NEWS&ArtNo=604040332&S&p=all |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} In June, the Harris campaign received a legal bill for thousands of dollars that contained a reference to "DOJ [[subpoena]]". Later, an ex-aide told the [[Associated Press]] that Harris had received a [[grand jury]] subpoena from federal investigators, but kept it from her top advisers, prompting several staff members to quit when they found out.{{cite news |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Ex-Aide-Says-Harris-Hid-Subpoena/id-2287bdcb69eb3c33e47675fca082670c |title=Ex-Aide Says Harris Hid Subpoena |author=Farrington, Brendan |date=August 2, 2006 |agency=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510202447/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Ex-Aide-Says-Harris-Hid-Subpoena/id-2287bdcb69eb3c33e47675fca082670c |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} On June 8, 2006, Harris's fourth chief of staff, Fred Asbell, left in order to pursue a "business opportunity". Asbell said he'd "greatly enjoyed" his time with the campaign and he would remain in a consultant position.Stratton, Jim (June 8, 2006). [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-06-09/news/HARRIS09_1_fred-asbell-katherine-harris-harris-announced "Harris loses 4th chief of staff"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510203158/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-06-09/news/HARRIS09_1_fred-asbell-katherine-harris-harris-announced|date=May 10, 2014}}. ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]''. On July 12, 2006, Harris's campaign spokesman Chris Christopher Ingram left the campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/content/more-trouble-harris |title=More trouble for Harris? |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=July 12, 2006 |accessdate=August 17, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015035214/http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/the-buzz-florida-politics/content/more-trouble-harris |archivedate=October 15, 2012 |deadurl=no}} The next day, Harris received resignations from Campaign Manager Glenn Hodas, Field Director Pat Thomas, Political Director Brian Brooks and Deputy Field Director John K. Byers, while Travel Aide Kyle Johnson and Field Director Mike Norris declined to leave, citing loyalty to Harris.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060714/NEWS/607140301&p=all |title=Five staffers leave Harris campaign |author=Wallace, Jeremey |date=July 14, 2006 |work=Sarasota Herald-Tribune |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510212255/http://www.heraldtribune.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060714%2FNEWS%2F607140301&p=all |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} Hodas cited Harris's "tantrums" and "increasingly erratic behavior" as his reasons for leaving.{{cite web|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Another-Harris-Campaign-Staffer-Quits/id-70a655d7769bc292741e58e5c1ed18b9|title=Another Harris Campaign Staffer Quits |author=Farrington, Brendan |date=July 14, 2006 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510212754/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2006/Another-Harris-Campaign-Staffer-Quits/id-70a655d7769bc292741e58e5c1ed18b9 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} An anonymous campaign worker described Harris as "very difficult to work with. The more that we put her out there, the more she shot herself in the foot."{{cite news | title=Harris Campaign Staff Quits (Again) | publisher=Political Wire |date=February 26, 2006 |url=http://politicalwire.com/archives/2006/07/12/harris_campaign_staff_quits_again.html|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071127085605/http://politicalwire.com/archives/2006/07/12/harris_campaign_staff_quits_again.html |archivedate=November 27, 2007|deadurl=yes}} In late August, Harris lost another key staffer, Rhyan Metzler, in the wake of a disastrous political rally at Orlando Executive Airport. Only 40 people showed up for the event, and Harris blamed the paltry turnout in part on a last-minute change in location. She claimed that a tree fell on the hangar that was originally scheduled to hold the rally, forcing her campaign to switch to another hangar. Airport officials, however, stated that not only had no trees fallen, but also that there are no trees as they get in the way of the airplanes; further adding that the event in fact took place in the hangar that Harris's campaign had originally booked. Harris's campaign blamed Metzler for the comments Harris made after the rally.{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-08-22/news/STBRIEFS22_3_1_harris-metzler-hangar |title=Harris loses another staffer |publisher=Orlando Sentinel |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510215219/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-08-22/news/STBRIEFS22_3_1_harris-metzler-hangar |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} On August 31, 2006, Harris was interviewed on ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'', where she responded to the criticisms from her former staffers with "We have their email traffic, we know what was behind all that, we know who's been paid and who isn't."{{cite web| url=http://www.rawstory.com/news/2006/Video_Katherine_Harris_claims_a_wave_0831.html |title=Video: Katherine Harris claims 'a wave of support' for Senate bid |date=August 31, 2006 |work=The Raw Story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071127062150/http://www.rawstory.com/news/2006/Video_Katherine_Harris_claims_a_wave_0831.html |archivedate=November 27, 2007 |deadurl=no}} ====Lack of Republican support==== The ''[[Pensacola News Journal]]'' suggested that Harris might withdraw from the Senate race after winning a primary victory, thereby allowing the Republicans to nominate another candidate, such as [[Tom Gallagher]], to run against [[Bill Nelson (politician)]].{{cite news|url=http://www.pensacolanewsjournal.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060726/NEWS01/607260337/1006 |title=Harris win could pose bizarre twist. Some speculate on primary victory followed by withdrawal from Senate race |author=Wheeler, Larry |date=July 26, 2006 |work=Pensacola News-Journal |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510220109/http://www.pnj.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060726%2FNEWS01%2F607260337%2F1006 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} In August, Katherine Harris touted political endorsements from fellow Republican lawmakers on her campaign web site. However, some of those cited claim that they never endorsed her. This conflict resulted in several Republican congressmen calling the Harris campaign to complain after the ''St. Petersburg Times'' notified them of the endorsements listed on Harris's Web site. A short time later, their names were removed without comment from Harris's Web site.{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/08/17/State/Backing_Harris_Her_li.shtml |title=Backing Harris? Her list shortens |author=Kumar, Anita |work=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=August 17, 2006 |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523234208/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/08/17/State/Backing_Harris_Her_li.shtml |archivedate=May 23, 2011 |deadurl=no}} Of Harris's three primary opponents, only Will McBride endorsed her candidacy for the general election. In the first few days after the primary, a number of Republican nominees such as [[Charlie Crist]] and [[Tom Lee (politician)|Tom Lee]] went on a statewide unity tour with Gov. Bush. Harris was not invited; Republicans said the tour was only for nominees to statewide offices. Harris claimed Bush would campaign with her sometime in the two months before the election, but the governor's office denied this.{{cite news | url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-09-09/news/HARRIS09_1_1_katherine-harris-todd-harris-jeb-bush | title=Harris, GOP differ on Jeb Bush commitment | author=Stratton, Jim |author2=Sashin, Daphne |date=September 9, 2006 |work=Orlando Sentinel |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810202258/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2006-09-09/news/HARRIS09_1_1_katherine-harris-todd-harris-jeb-bush |archivedate=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=no}} President Bush did not make public appearances or private meetings with Harris before the primary. He did, however, appear with her at a fundraiser on September 21 in Tampa. When it came time for newspapers to make their op-ed endorsements, all 22 of Florida's major daily newspapers supported Senator Nelson. The only endorsement Harris received was from the ''[[Polk County Democrat]]'', a newspaper in [[Bartow, Florida|Bartow]] which publishes four days out of the week.{{cite news | url=http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/katherine_harris_0-22_in_florida_newspaper_endorsements/| title=Katherine Harris 0–22 in Florida Newspaper Endorsements | author=Joyner, James |date=October 30, 2006 |publisher=Outside the Beltway |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620092219/http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/katherine_harris_0-22_in_florida_newspaper_endorsements |archivedate=June 20, 2013 |deadurl=no}} ====Religious convictions==== Harris was a headline speaker at the [[Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church]]'s "Reclaiming America for Christ" conference held in Ft. Lauderdale on March 17–18, 2006. The conference web site invited attendees to attend in order to "reclaim this nation for Christ."{{cite web|url=http://www.reclaimamerica.org/PAGES/CONFERENCES/RAC2006/default.asp |title=Coral Ridge Ministries |publisher=Reclaimamerica.org |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060318033722/http://www.reclaimamerica.org/PAGES/CONFERENCES/RAC2006/default.asp |archivedate=March 18, 2006 |deadurl=yes}} The stated mission of ReclaimAmerica.org is "To inform, equip, motivate, and support Christians; enabling them to defend and implement the Biblical principles on which our country was founded."{{cite web|url=http://www.reclaimamerica.org/pages/aboutus.aspx |title=Coral Ridge Ministries |publisher=Reclaimamerica.org |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060213180002/http://www.reclaimamerica.org/pages/aboutus.aspx |archivedate=February 2006 |deadurl=no}} As part of her speech, Harris urged conferees to "win back America for God." Her appearance was noted in a ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' article covering the conference.{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/7235393/the_crusaders/ |author=Moser, Bob |date=April 7, 2005 |title=The Crusaders |work=Rolling Stone |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318185336/http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/7235393/the_crusaders/ |archivedate=March 18, 2008 |deadurl=no}} In an interview with the ''Florida Baptist Witness'' on August 24, 2006, Harris called for Christians to vote on religious lines. She said, {{quote|We have to have the faithful in government and over time, that lie we have been told, the [[separation of church and state]], people have internalized, thinking that they needed to avoid politics and that is so wrong because God is the one who chooses our rulers. And if we are the ones not actively involved in electing those godly men and women and if people aren't involved in helping godly men in getting elected then we're going to have a nation of secular laws. That's not what our [[Founding Fathers of the United States|founding fathers]] intended and that's certainly isn't what God intended. ... we need to take back this country. ... And if we don't get involved as Christians then how could we possibly take this back? ... If you are not electing Christians, tried and true, under public scrutiny and pressure, if you're not electing Christians then in essence you are going to legislate sin. They can legislate sin. They can say that abortion is alright. They can vote to sustain [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|gay marriage]]. And that will take western civilization, indeed other nations because people look to our country as one nation as under God and whenever we legislate sin and we say abortion is permissible and we say gay unions are permissible, then average citizens who are not Christians, because they don't know better, we are leading them astray and it's wrong.{{cite news| publisher=Florida Baptist Witness|url=http://gofbw.com/news.asp?ID=6298 | title=Katherine Harris|date=August 24, 2006 |accessdate=January 9, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070107022628/http://www.floridabaptistwitness.com/6298.article |archivedate=January 7, 2007 |deadurl=no}}}} Rep. [[Debbie Wasserman Schultz]] (D-FL) said she was "disgusted" by the comments "and deeply disappointed in Representative Harris personally," adding "clearly shows that she does not deserve to be a representative."{{cite news|title=Rep. Harris Condemns Separation of Church, State |author=Stratton, Jim |publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date= August 26, 2006| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/08/25/AR2006082501640.html |accessdate=January 9, 2007}} Two of Harris' primary opponents denounced her statements, Republican [[Will McBride (politician)|Will McBride]] (an attorney and son of a pastor) stated "I'm a Christian, and I'm a Republican, and I don't share her views. There are people of other faiths and backgrounds of outstanding integrity who know how to tell the truth." [[Real estate developer]] [[Peter Monroe]], another GOP primary opponent, called on her to quit the race and resign from Congress. He called her suggestion that non-Christian voters are ignorant of morality when voting as "contemptible, arrogant and wicked."{{cite news|title=Katherine Harris tries to quell furor over remarks in Baptist newspaper| author=Marus, Robert | date=August 28, 2006|url=http://www.abpnews.com/archives/item/1440-katherine-harris-tries-to-quell-furor-over-remarks-in-baptist-newspaper |accessdate=January 9, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061029040211/http://www.abpnews.com/1327.article |archivedate=October 29, 2006 |deadurl=no}} On August 26, 2006, Harris's campaign released a "Statement of Clarification", that stated, "In the interview, Harris was speaking to a Christian audience, addressing a common misperception that people of faith should not be actively involved in government. Addressing this Christian publication, Harris provided a statement that explains her deep grounding in [[Judeo-Christian]] values." The press release went on to mention her past support of [[Israel]] and quoted her Jewish campaign manager [[Bryan G. Rudnick]], who stated "As the grandson of [[Holocaust]] survivors, I know that she encourages people of all faiths to engage in government so that our country can continue to thrive on the principles set forth by our founding fathers, without malice towards anyone." At an appearance at an [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] gun show that same day, she said "it breaks my heart" to think people understood her comments as bigoted. When asked if she thought the Founding Fathers intended the nation to have secular laws she replied, {{quote|I think that our laws, I mean, I look at how the law originated, even from [[Moses]], the [[Ten Commandments]]. And I don't believe, that uh. ... That's how all of our laws originated in the United States, period. I think that's the basis of our rule of law.}} On October 3, 2006, Harris participated in a prayer service via phone call. In one instance, she called for the elimination of the separation of church and state when she said, {{quote|Treat the pastors' hearts so that those who think there's no place for government, have them understand kingdom government, and how they need to be involved in the governance on this earth because God is our governance.}} Harris then went on and prayed for Jews to be converted to Christianity. {{quote|And Father God, right now on the day after the Jewish new year, Father, after the day after atonement, as they enter into their new year, Father God, I just pray that you would bring the hearts and minds of our Jewish brothers and sisters into alignment.{{cite news |url=http://www.tbo.com/news/politics/MGBNSMYJ3UE.html |work=Tampa Tribune |title=Harris' Prayer Call Stirs Concerns |author=March, William |date=November 4, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071126055759/http://www.tbo.com/news/politics/MGBNSMYJ3UE.html |archivedate=November 26, 2007 |deadurl=no }}{{cite web|url=http://wonkette.com/212673/katherine-harris-prays-for-the-realignment-of-the-chosen-people |title=Katherine Harris Prays For the Realignment of the Chosen People |author=Pareene, Alex |publisher=wonkette.com |date=November 6, 2006 |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517194327/http://wonkette.com/212673/katherine-harris-prays-for-the-realignment-of-the-chosen-people |archivedate=May 17, 2011 |deadurl=no}}}} ====Replacements in the 13th Congressional District==== [[Vern Buchanan]] was the Republican nominee and [[Christine Jennings]] the Democratic nominee to replace Harris in the [[United States House elections, 2006#Florida|2006 election]]. The race had been ranked as "leaning Democratic" by [[CQ Politics]], but Buchanan scored a very narrow victory, winning the election by a few hundred votes. ==Political positions and voting record== Harris is a conservative on most issues. She is [[pro-life]] and has voted against [[embryonic stem cell research]]. She opposes oil-drilling in Florida's coastal waters.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} Harris supported reforming [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] to include private accounts. She has voted in favor of granting legal status to [[fetus]]es via the [[Unborn Victims of Violence Act]]. She supports [[tax cuts]] and the [[Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act]], which restricts bankruptcy filings by consumers. Harris is also in favor of [[welfare reform]], [[school vouchers]], the [[Patriot Act]], the [[Flag Desecration Amendment]], the [[Federal Marriage Amendment]], and the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]].{{cite web |url=http://www.issues2002.org/Senate/Katherine_Harris.htm |title=Katherine Harris Voting Record |publisher=issues2002.org |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629015612/http://issues2002.org/Senate/Katherine_Harris.htm |archivedate=June 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} In a televised debate with Nelson on November 1, however, she repeatedly declined to say whether she would still support the [[Iraq Resolution|Iraq War Resolution]] knowing that [[Iraq]] did not have [[weapons of mass destruction]].{{cite web|author=Hoar, Jennifer |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/11/02/politics/main2146464.shtml |title=Harris Pressed On WMD Issue In Fla. Debate |publisher=CBS News |date=November 2, 2006 |accessdate=March 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140510230544/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/harris-pressed-on-wmd-issue-in-fla-debate/ |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no}} In an earlier debate with Nelson, Harris was asked to comment on trade of arms with foreign nations and the potential threat of their acquisition by terrorist groups. Harris responded that "we know we don't want to have arms going to the rogue nations like China."{{cite web |title=Katherine Harris during the debate |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipk1GzEYuHU |accessdate=October 25, 2008}} ==Later life== Harris has not been very active in public life since retiring from politics. In 2013, her husband, Swedish-born businessman Anders Ebbeson, shot himself{{cite news|last1=Murgatroyd|first1=John|last2=Morrison|first2=Jamie|title=Husband of Katherine Harris kills himself, police say|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/11/19/politics/harris-husband-suicide/|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=November 22, 2013|accessdate=July 18, 2017}} in the [[Sarasota, Florida|Sarasota]] home they shared; he had reportedly been suffering a serious illness. Three years later, she attended a reunion of former Florida legislators in Tallahassee,{{cite news|last=Carrejo|first=Cate|title=What Is Katherine Harris Doing Now? The Politician Has Been Laying Low For Years|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/140234-what-is-katherine-harris-doing-now-the-politician-has-been-laying-low-for-years|newspaper=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]|date=February 8, 2016|accessdate=July 18, 2017}} and in 2017, after admitting she'd become "a near recluse" since Ebbeson's death, she married Texas banker Richard Ware.{{cite news|last=Lambiet|first=Jose|title=2000 election kingpin Katherine Harris to marry Texas tycoon|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/entertainment/ent-columns-blogs/jose-lambiet/article133870539.html|newspaper=[[Miami Herald]]|date=February 20, 2017|accessdate=July 18, 2017}} ==In popular culture== Katherine Harris was the subject of some popular skits on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', in which she was played by [[Ana Gasteyer]]; she was also portrayed by actress [[Laura Dern]] in the 2008 film ''[[Recount (film)|Recount]]'', which won Dern a [[Golden Globe]] for the role. Harris is also referenced in one of filmmaker [[Kevin Smith]]'s monologues for the DVD ''[[An Evening with Kevin Smith 2: Evening Harder]]''. ==See also== * [[Florida election recount]] * [[Women in the United States House of Representatives]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} {{CongLinks|congbio=H001035}} * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/30/AR2006103001311_pf.html Profile piece at Washington Post] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Sandra Mortham]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Secretary of State of Florida]]|years=1999–2002}} {{s-aft|after=[[James C. Smith|James Smith]]}} |- {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Dan Miller (Florida politician)|Dan Miller]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Florida|U.S. House of Representatives]]
from [[Florida's 13th congressional district]]|years=2003–2007}} {{s-aft|after=[[Vern Buchanan]]}} |- {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Bill McCollum]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for [[United States Senator|U.S. Senator]] from [[Florida]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2010}} '''Kapitan China Kee Kim Swee''' (or Kee Kim Sui, also known as Kee Abdullah after he converted to Islam) was one of the prominent and important Chinese nationality ([[Hainanese]]) who settled in [[Tawau]], [[Sabah]]. He was appointed as the first customs examiner and revenue collector by the British North Borneo (Chartered) Company in Tawau, 1894. A year later, Tawau development was entrusted to his hands by the British administration. He became the first ''Pengulu'' or ''Orang Kaya'' (OKK) in Tawau, Sabah. Tawau (also known as Tanjung) became a modern town under Kee Kim Swee's lead, as he engineered Tawau into a business and commercial area in the early 1900s.<ref>Bernama [http://thestar.com.my/metro/story.asp?file=/2008/9/25/southneast/2093010&sec=southneast], "The Star", Thursday, 25 September 2008.</ref>
After he died, his son OKK Kee Abu Bakar became his successor as the ''Penghulu''.
==Early life and career==
Kee Abdullah (Kee Kim Swee) was born in 1863. Little is known about his biological mother. He had a step-parent known by the name Kipas, a Dusun Tidong woman from Brunei.
In 1883, at the age of 20 years, as the courteous and respected Agent of the Company in Brunei, [[Kapitan Cina|Kapitan]] Kee Kim Swee was appointed as Datuk Temenggung over the Chinese community by [[Abdul Momin|Sultan Abdul Momin]].<ref>Sabah State Archive, "The North Borneo Herald" 1 July 1883.</ref>
In 1885, while on a trading journey with his father to Sandakan, their [[Tongkang]] boat encountered a mishap and capsized at the Marudu Bay. His father of Hainanese origin died in the incident and was buried in a Chinese cemetery in the district of [[Kudat]], Sabah. Kee Kim Swee survived and was rescued by villagers. He settled in the residence of a Suluk man named Dato Husin until his recovery.
In 1894, Kee Kim Swee was recruited by the British North Borneo Chartered Company as a customs examiner and revenue collector in Tawau. One of his many tasks was to collect a one-dollar [[Tax per head|poll tax]] from the residents. His unique ability to converse in Arabic, and also Jawi literate, served as a link between the native and Chinese groups with the government. Thus, he was often called upon for his view and to provide representation.<ref>Chung, Nicholas. "Under the Borneo Sun : A Tawau Story". [[Natural History Publications (Borneo)|Natural History Publication Borneo]], 2005. {{ISBN|983-812-108-8}}, {{ISBN|983-812-108-8}}</ref>
==Family==
He converted to Islam when he married a Mindanao girl of Sulu Parang Tapol, Jumaatiah Ame Maidin, and later changed his name into Kee Abdullah.<ref>[http://www.google.com.my/search?tbm=bks&tbo=1&q=+Kee+Kim+Swee&btnG=#sclient=psy&hl=en&tbo=1&tbm=bks&source=hp&q=Kee+Kim+Swee%2C+a+Sino-Dusun+born&pbx=1&oq=Kee+Kim+Swee%2C+a+Sino-Dusun+born&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&gs_sm=e&gs_upl=11234l11234l0l12132l1l1l0l0l0l0l0l0ll0l0&fp=efdbfb56a135dd13&biw=1138&bih=555 Malaysian Chinese and Nation-building: Historical background and economic perspective, Hua she yan jiu zhong xin]</ref> His marriage with Jumaatiah gave him 18 children, 13 boys and 5 girls.
His children with Jumaatiah Ame Maidin:
* Kee Sulaiman (1897–1977) * Kee Othman (1898–1970) * OKK Kee Abu Bakar (1899–1953) * Kee Abdul Aziz (unknown) * Child name not recorded * Kee Aishah (1906–1985) * Kee Sidek (1909–1945) * Kee Hatifah (1910–1969) * Kee Ali (1913–1975) * Kee A. Kamaruddin (1915-unknown) * Kee A. Omar (1916–1931) * Child name not recorded * Kee Abdul Jalil (1919–1990) * Kee Dzawiyah (1920–1921) Some of the children's names were not recorded.
His early marriage with a Chinese woman from Kudat gave them 3 children, 2 boys and 1 girl. Both of his sons went back to China, while the girl changed her surname into "Chin" by marriage.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://keeheritage.forumotion.com/forum.htm Kee Heritage Forum]
