revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}}
[[File:PrimeMinisterAliKhanNewOrleansAirportWreath1950.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Liaquat Ali Khan]] and [[First Lady of Pakistan|First Lady]] [[Ra'ana Liaquat Ali Khan|Sheila Irene Pant]] are welcomed at [[Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport|New Orleans Airport]]. Garlands of flowers presented by the American public greet Prime Minister Ali Khan and his wife.]]
The '''state visit of Liaquat Ali Khan to the United States''' from 3 May to 26 May 1950, was an official [[state visit]] paid by the [[List of Prime Ministers of Pakistan|first]] [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]], [[Liaquat Ali Khan]], accompanied by the [[First Lady of Pakistan|First Lady]] of Pakistan, [[Ra'ana Liaquat Ali Khan|Sheila Irene Pant]].
Personal initiatives and invitation facilitated by the President of the United States, [[Harry S. Truman|Harry Truman]], Prime Minister of Pakistan Ali Khan and First Lady of Pakistan [[Ra'ana Liaquat Ali Khan|Begum Ali Khan]], were received by the general [[Americans|American public]] when the [[Pakistan International Airlines|state airlines]] carrying the delegation landed at the [[Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport|New Orleans Airport]], [[New Orleans]], Louisiana.<ref name="Jang English Services">{{cite news|last=Aziz|first=Qutubuddin|title=Special Edition: Quaid-i-Millat's visit to the United States The foundation of friendship and economic co-operation|url=http://jang.com.pk/thenews/spedition/liaqat_ali_khan/page2.htm.html|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=Jang English Services|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906181345/http://www.jang.com.pk/thenews/spedition/liaqat_ali_khan/page2.htm.html|archivedate=6 September 2008}}</ref> Upon Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]]'s arrival, there was an official parade in the New York City in his honour, he was also conferred with an honorary degree by the [[Columbia University]]. During his visit, he also spoke at the [[US House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], the [[lower house]] of the [[U.S. Congress|United States Congress]].<ref name="The Friday Times">{{cite news|last=Staff editor|title=Pakistan Chronicle's collection: Liaquat Ali Khan goes to the US (1950)|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=The Friday Times|url=http://www.thefridaytimes.com/beta2/tft/article.php?issue=20110930&page=30|date=6 October 2011}}</ref>
At home front, Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]]'s trip to the United States was highly politicised and criticised by the [[Socialism in Pakistan|left–wing]] sphere who levelled its charges on ignoring the [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics|Soviet Union]]'s invitation in favour of the United States.<ref name="Dawn news foreign policy archives">{{cite news|last=Staff writer|title=The foreign policy of Liaquat Ali Khan|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/881096/the-foreign-policy-of-liaquat-ali-khan|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=Dawn news foreign policy archives|date=17 October 2010}}</ref> Upon returning to Pakistan, Ali Khan spoke highly of his visit to the US but survived a [[Rawalpindi conspiracy|conspiracy hatched]] by the [[Socialism in Pakistan|left–wing]] sphere in 1951. According to the [[Pakistani English|English newspaper]], ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'', Ali Khan's state visit and further reliance towards the United States became a permanent fixture of the [[Foreign policy of Pakistan|foreign policy]] of Pakistan during the [[Cold War]].<ref name="Dawn News">{{cite news|last=Makhdumi|first=Umar M.|title=Liaquat Ali Khan's visit to US|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1003958/liaquat-ali-khan-s-visit-to-us|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=Dawn News|date=11 November 2011}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Nawabzada Liaquat Ali Khan President Truman.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Prime minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] shakes hands with President [[Harry S. Truman|Harry Truman]], upon his arrival.]] After the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of [[Pakistan]] in 1947, the United States was one of the first countries to recognise the new State of Pakistan as [[US Department of State]] had rushed the US Consul-General in [[Morocco]] to Karachi to represent the [[US government]] in the Pakistan's [[Independence Day (Pakistan)|Independence Day]] ceremony on [[Fourteenth of August|14 August 1947]] with a message of warm greetings and good wishes from the [[White House]].<ref name="Jang English Services" />
The [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of Pakistan in 1947 oversaw the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1947|first war]] over [[Kashmir]] region.<ref name="Jang English Services" /> During the war, [[Founder of Pakistan|Founder]] of Pakistan and [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] unsuccessfully asked the United States for [[United States dollar|$2 billion]] in military and financial aid but the US followed a policy of [[Neutrality (international relations)|neutrality]], rebuffing any requests made by Pakistan's government.<ref name="Har-Anand Publications" /> During this time, Pakistan's relations with the [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics|USSR]] remained to be fluctuated. In 1949, Indian Prime minister [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] paid the state visit to the United States, which eventually led Pakistan's government to cement relations with the [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Har-Anand Publications" /> Finally on 3 June 1949, Soviet Union sent an invitation to Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] which came as a surprise to the United States.<ref name="Har-Anand Publications" /> With India's [[Role of India in Non-aligned movement|strict commitment]] towards the [[Non-aligned Movement]] (NAM) influenced the United States to send an invitation to Ali Khan in 1950.<ref name="Har-Anand Publications" />
==Visit and aftermath== [[File:Photograph of President Truman and Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan of Pakistan in Washington during the Prime... - NARA - 200197.jpg|250px|left|thumb|President Truman accompanies Prime Minister Ali Khan in Washington D.C.]]
In a reference written by Kalim Bahadur in his book ''Democracy in Pakistan: Crises and Conflicts'', Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] quickly accepted the invitation and postponed his visit to Moscow.<ref name="Har-Anand Publications">{{cite book|last=Bahadur|first=Kalim|title=Democracy in Pakistan : crises and conflicts|year=1998|publisher=Har-Anand Publications|location=New Delhi|isbn=8124100837|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ND9yNyTpntYC&pg=PA232&dq=liaquat+ali+khan+visit+to+usa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KRsxU_zbBsjhyQHD34B4&ved=0CDAQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=liaquat%20ali%20khan%20visit%20to%20usa&f=true}}</ref> On 3 May 1950, Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]], the [[First Lady of Pakistan|First Lady]] of Pakistan, Begum Ali Khan and the large civic-military delegation arrived to the United States via United Kingdom and their [[Pakistan International|official flight]] landed at the [[Louis Armstrong New Orleans International Airport|New Orleans Airport]], [[New Orleans]], Louisiana.<ref name="Greenwood Press">{{cite book|last=Graebner|first=M. Srinivas Chary ; foreword by Norman A.|title=The eagle and the peacock : U.S. foreign policy toward India since independence|year=1994|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Conn.|isbn=0313276021|edition=1. publ.}}</ref> Prime Minister Ali Khan was met with honour and received a warm welcome from the general [[Americans|American public]]; he was personally received by the President of the United States, [[Harry S. Truman|Harry Truman]]. Upon reaching New York City, President Truman organised a parade and accorded the red-carpet treatment to welcome Ali Khan and his family.<ref name="Author House Public. Co.">{{cite book|last=Goswami|first=Arvind|title=3 D Deceit, Duplicity & Dissimulation of U.S. Foreign Policy towards India|year=2012|publisher=Author House Public. Co.|isbn=1477257098|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=amkR1LkaQmQC&pg=PA79&dq=liaquat+ali+khan+visit+to+usa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KRsxU_zbBsjhyQHD34B4&ved=0CDsQuwUwAg#v=onepage&q=liaquat%20ali%20khan%20visit%20to%20usa&f=true}}</ref>
Ali Khan gave a lecture on [[political science]] at [[Columbia University]], which conferred him with an honorary degree. Thereafter, he also engaged and spoke to the [[US House of Representatives]]. Speaking at the [[United States Congress]] session, Ali Khan highlighted the importance of Pakistan's geostrategic location, and the visit set the course of Pakistan's foreign policy: close ties with the United States and co-operation against a perceived threat from the USSR. Upon returning to Pakistan, he strongly defended his trip to the United States in a broadcast from [[Radio Pakistan]] on 30 June: {{quote|This visit not only enabled me to see the American people and their wonderful country but also gave me an occasion to inform the inhabitants of that country about the birth of Pakistan, its short but eventful history and the Islamic way of life adopted as an ideal by the people of my country|sign=Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan, 1950|source=source<ref name="Jang English Services" /> }}
==Criticism and politicisation== At home front, Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] was highly politicised and criticised by the [[Socialism in Pakistan|left-wing sphere]] who charged him with ignoring the [[Soviet Union]]'s initiation. However, Ali Khan counter-argued that the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] had slowly extended the invitation and "were unable to fix a date to pay a state visit." Ali Khan's state visit and alignment towards the United States became a pivot in Pakistan's [[Foreign policy of Pakistan|foreign policy]] during the [[Cold War]]. After the [[Assassination of Liaquat Ali Khan|assassination]] of Ali Khan, the relations with the USSR soured until 1965 when the relations improved to such an extent that USSR sponsored the [[Tashkent Agreement]] between India and Pakistan.
In 1972, due to Prime Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]]'s [[rapprochement]], [[1972 Bhutto visit to Soviet Union|visit led to normalise]] the relation after providing a help to finance the founding of Pakistan's largest industrial complex: [[Pakistan Steel Mills]]. In a critical assessment opinion written in [[Pakistani English|English newspaper]] ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'', Liaquat Ali Khan is chiefly responsible for throwing Pakistan into the US camp.
==Media gallery== <gallery> File:PrimeMinisterAliKhanSpeaksInNewOrleans1950.jpg|Prime Minister Ali Khan speaking with the American public. File:Begum Liaquat Ali Meets President of MIT.jpg|Prime Minister Ali Khan and First Lady [[Ra'ana Liaquat Ali Khan|Begum Ali Khan]] speaks with the faculty of [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]. File:Barkley showing Vice Presidents seal to Ali Khan.jpg|Vice-President [[Alben Barkley]] explains the 1948 version [[Great Seal of the United States|US Seal]]. </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Bahadur, Kalim (1998). ''Democracy in Pakistan : crises and conflicts''. New Delhi: Har-Anand Publications. {{ISBN|8124100837}}.
{{Pakistan–United States relations}}

{{Lists of Britons}} {{main|British Chinese}} This article is a list of prominent people of [[China|Chinese]] ancestry who were born in or have settled in the [[United Kingdom]].
To be included in this list, the person must have a Wikipedia article showing they are British Chinese or must have references showing they are British Chinese and are notable. ==Academia== * [[Kevin Fong]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=194381|title='With a name like Kevin Fong, I was expecting ...|work=Times Higher Education}}</ref> professor of [[medicine]], [[University College London|UCL]] academic. * [[Charles K. Kao]], [[KBE]], [[Nobel Prize in Physics]], pioneer in the development and use of fibre-optics in telecommunications
==Acting== * [[Leah Bracknell]], actress and Yoga teacher, Eurasian, English father and Chinese-Malaysian mother * [[Naomi Campbell]], fashion model, actress, singer, author; mixed Jamaican and Chinese ancestry * [[Gemma Chan]], actress * [[Daphne Cheung]], actress * [[Maggie Cheung]], actress * [[Yao Chin]], actor, journalist and news broadcaster * [[Paul Courtenay Hyu]], actor, writer and [[Elvis impersonator]], Eurasian * [[Jon Foo]], actor and wushu martial artist * [[Jessica Henwick]], actress, Eurasian * [[Sandrine Holt]], Canadian actress * [[Burt Kwouk]], actor * [[Pui Fan Lee]], actress and television presenter * [[Jing Lusi]], actress * [[Katie Leung]], actress, [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[Chinese people|Chinese]] * [[Max Minghella]], actor, Eurasian * [[Suan-Li Ong]] actress-model * Lucy Sheen, actor, writer, filmmaker, British Hong Kong Chinese<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0790686/|title=Lucy Sheen|website=IMDb|access-date=29 October 2017}}</ref> * [[Elizabeth Tan]], actress * [[Benedict Wong]], actor * [[Tom Wu]], actor * [[David Yip]], actor, Eurasian
==Art and design== * [[Suki Chan]], British Chinese artist * [[Aowen Jin]], British Chinese artist and social commentator * [[Qu Lei Lei]], artist and calligrapher<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/qu_lei_lei/|title=Qu Lei Lei|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Cary Kwok]], artist * [[Chris Liu]], fashion designer * [[Beatrix Ong]], luxury fashion accessory and shoe designer * [[Gok Wan]], fashion consultant and television presenter<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/gok_wan/|title=Gok Wan|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref>
==Business== * [[Andrew Ng]], co-founder of education technology company [[Coursera]], director of [[Stanford University]]'s Artificial Intelligence Lab<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.stanford.edu/people/ang/|title=Home - Andrew Ng|work=Andrew Ng|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * Sir [[David Tang]], founder of fashion chain [[Shanghai Tang]], socialite and writer * [[Woon Wing Yip]], founder of the British Chinese supermarket chain [[Wing Yip]]
==Food== * [[Murder of Mi Gao Huang Chen|Mi Gao Huang Chen]], takeaway owner who was murdered in 2005 * [[Ching He Huang|Ching-He Huang]], food broadcaster and food writer * [[Nancy Lam]], chef<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/nancy_lam/|title=Nancy Lam|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[William Poon|Willian "Bill" Poon]], chef and restaurateur<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/bill_poon/|title=Bill Poon|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Alan Yau]], restaurateur, founder of [[Wagamama]], [[Hakkasan]] and [[Yauatcha]]
==Music== * [[Ayi Jihu]], singer<ref>{{citation|title=剑桥彝族美女吉胡阿依:英国第一位Hip Hop中国女歌手/Cambridge ethnic Yi girl Jihu Ayi: UK's first Chinese female hip-hop artist|periodical=New Youth|date=September 2008|url=http://cn.qikan.com/Article/xqin/xqin200809/xqin20080933.html|author=Lu Chaoran/吕超然|accessdate=2010-01-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716192508/http://cn.qikan.com/Article/xqin/xqin200809/xqin20080933.html|archivedate=2012-07-16|df=}}</ref> * [[Liao Zilan|Zilan Liao,]] guzheng, concert harp and director of Pagoda arts * [[Jason Lai]], orchestral conductor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/jason_lai/|title=Jason Lai|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Herman Li]], of the power metal band [[DragonForce]] * [[Jiang Li (musician)|Jiang Li]], [[musician]] and [[composer]] musician<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/jiang_li/|title=Jiang Li|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Jasmine Thompson]], singer * Matt Tong, drummer of indie rock bands [[Bloc Party]] and [[Algiers (band)|Algiers]] <ref>[http://mog.com/cyberred/blog/1239853 mog.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724000833/http://mog.com/cyberred/blog/1239853 |date=July 24, 2009 }}</ref> * [[Fou Ts'ong]], pianist * [[KT Tunstall]], musician * [[Vanessa-Mae]], violinist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/vanessa_mae/|title=Vanessa Mae|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Jamie Woon]], [[dubstep]] artist * [[Cheng Yu (musician)|Cheng Yu]], [[pipa]] and [[guqin]] musician<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/cheng_yu/|title=Cheng Yu|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Guo Yue (musician)|Guo Yue]], [[dizi (musical instrument)|dizi]] and [[bawu]] musician
==Politics== * [[Michael Chan, Baron Chan]], politician, life peer in the [[House of Lords]] * [[Steven Dominique Cheung]], [[Diana Memorial Award|Diana Award]] winner, youngest candidate for the European Election in 2009, DJ of Spectrum Radio and SW1 Radio<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pswu.com/sccn/558/2009/04/07/303|title=CHINESE YOUTH SEEKS TO BE THE YOUNGEST EVER EUROPEAN MEP IN LONDON|work=pswu.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223003520/http://pswu.com/sccn/558/2009/04/07/303|archive-date=23 February 2012|date=7 April 2009|author=Joseph Wu|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Alan Mak (politician)|Alan Mak]], Member of Parliament for [[Havant (UK Parliament constituency)|Havant]] since 2015, first British Chinese member of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] * [[Nat Wei, Baron Wei]], social entrepreneur, former government advisor and member of the House of Lords<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/nat_wei_baron_wei/|title=Lord Wei of Shoreditch (Nat Wei)|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref>
==Sport== * [[Sammy Chung]], only person of Chinese descent to manage an English football league club * [[Frank Soo]], first player of Chinese descent to play in the [[Football League]], and the first non-white player to represent England * [[Alex Hua Tian]], Olympic event rider,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/olympics/2007-08/22/content_6036154.htm|title=Eton schoolboy gallops toward Beijing Games|work=ChinaDaily.com.cn|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> gave up his British Citizenship in order to compete in the 2008 Beijing Olympics as part of the Chinese team * [[Rory Underwood]], former [[England|English]] [[rugby union]] rugby player, Eurasian
==Television== * [[Alexa Chung]], TV presenter, fashion model, contributing editor at British ''Vogue''; Eurasian
==Writers== * [[Jung Chang]], writer, co-author of the biography ''[[Mao: The Unknown Story]]'' * [[Leslie Charteris]], writer and creator of antihero [[Simon Templar]], alias The Saint * [[Jo Ho]], screenwriter, director, and first Chinese person in the UK to create a television drama series, the 2010 BBC fantasy ''[[Spirit Warriors]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0387311|title= Jo Ho|publisher=IMDb.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Hsiung Shih-I]], writer who became the first Chinese person to write and direct a West End play in 1935<ref>{{cite episode|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/chinese_in_britain8.shtml|title=Episode 8: Artistic pursuits|series=Chinese in Britain|network=BBC Radio 4|airdate=9 May 2007|access-date=7 February 2011}}</ref> * [[Chee Soo]], author and teacher on [[Taoism]], [[traditional Chinese medicine]] and martial arts * [[Xue Xinran]], broadcaster, author and founder of the charity Mother's Bridge of Love<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/xinran_xue/|title=Xinran Xue|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Benjamin Yeoh]], playwright<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visiblechinese.com/website/profile/benjamin_yeoh_seng_loong/|title=Benjamin Yeoh Seng-Loong|author=Visible Chinese|work=VisibleChinese.com|access-date=27 July 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Chinese clan]] * [[Overseas Chinese]] * [[List of overseas Chinese]] * [[List of Chinese Americans]] * [[List of Chinese Australians]] * [[List of Chinese Canadians]] * [[List of Chinese Filipinos]] * [[List of Malaysian Chinese]] * [[List of Chinese New Zealanders]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:British Chinese people}} [[Category:Lists of British people by origin|Chinese]] [[Category:Chinese diaspora]] [[Category:British people of Chinese descent| ]] [[Category:Lists of people by ethnicity|Chinese]] [[Category:Chinese community in the United Kingdom]]

This is a list of historical individuals notable for their [[Paganism|Pagan]] religion, and modern individuals who self-describe as adherents of some form of [[Paganism]] or [[Neopaganism]]. <!-- Only self-described Pagans or those independently documented as Pagans are to be listed! Entries must also meet Wikipedia's notability criteria and should not be added by the individual themselves (in other words, don't add yourself to the list). -->
==Ancient==
=== Baltic=== Historic [[Baltic paganism|Baltic pagans]]: * [[Algirdas]] (d. 1377), [[Lithuania]]n [[Grand Prince]]. * [[Kęstutis]], brother of Algirdas, killed 1382, for some time held title of [[Grand Prince]] of [[Lithuania]] after Algirdas' death. * [[Nameisis]] (d. after 1281), [[Semigallians|Semigallian]] Duke. * [[Viestards]] (d. 1230), [[Semigallians|Semigallian]] Duke. * [[Vytautas|Vytautas The Great]], [[Grand Duke]] of [[Lithuania]] and son of Kęstutis, baptized with his cousin [[Jogaila]] in 1386. * [[Jogaila]], King of Poland, baptized in 1386 and got new name – [[Władysław II Jagiełło]]. Together with Vytautas they are the last pagan monarchs of Europe. He gave name to [[Jagiellon]] branch of [[Gediminids]] – one of largest dynasties in medieval Europe.
===Celtic=== Pagans among the ancient Celtic peoples ([[Roman Gaul]], [[Roman Britain]], [[Ireland]])
Historic [[Celtic polytheism|Celtic pagans]]: *[[Caratacus]] (b. ca. 10 A.D.) Chieftain of the Catuvellauni tribe who led the British resistance to the Roman Conquest. *[[Boudica]] (b. ca. 30 A.D–60 A.D) Celtic warrior queen of the Iceni tribe who fought against the Roman oppression of Britain. *[[Niall of the Nine Hostages]] (d. ca. 405), according to legend kidnapped St. Patrick as a youth. *[[Radagaisus]] (d. 406) *[[Lóegaire mac Néill]] (fl. ca. 440s), according to [[Muirchu moccu Machtheni]] a "great, fierce, pagan emperor of the barbarians reigning in Tara." * [[Lughaid mac Loeguire]] (d. ca. 507) * [[Diarmait mac Cerbaill]] (d. 585), according to Irish tradition the last [[High King of Ireland]] to follow the pagan rituals of inauguration. * [[Gwenc'hlan]], legendary as the last [[Breton people|Breton]] bard and druid.
===Egyptian===
*[[Horapollo]], (5th Century) Egyptian pagan writer
===Germanic=== Historic [[Germanic paganism|Germanic pagans]]: * [[Athanaric]] (died 381), king of several branches of the [[Thervings]] for at least two decades in the fourth century. * [[Gibuld]] (fl. ca. 470), king of the [[Alamanni]] who freed hostages on the request of [[Severinus of Noricum|Saint Severinus of Noricum]]. * [[Penda of Mercia]] (d. 655), one of the last [[Anglo-Saxon paganism|pagan Anglo-Saxon]] rulers of [[England]]. * [[Arwald]] (d. 686), last pagan ruler of the [[Isle of Wight]], or any Anglo-Saxon kingdom. * [[Widukind]] (d. 808), pagan Saxon leader and the chief opponent of [[Charlemagne]] during the [[Saxon Wars]]. * [[Sweyn Forkbeard]] (d. 1014), pagan king of [[Denmark]]. * [[Palnetoke]], legendary pagan foster-father of Sweyn's * [[Blot-Sweyn]], leader of the Swedish pagan renaissance in the 11th century * [[Eric of Good Harvests]] (dead c. 1081), semi-historical successor to Blot-Sweyn, and the last pagan king in Scandinavia.
===Graeco-Roman=== Historic Graeco-Roman pagans: * [[Hadrian]] (76–138), completed the Temple of Olympian Zeus and was noted for strengthening ties between the Roman and Greek pantheons. * [[Decius]], Made efforts toward increasing public piety. Required sacrifices on behalf of the emperor (himself) which led to execution for those who refused, mostly non-Pagans. * [[Diocletian]], Noted for his piety and conservative Pagan views. Engaged in severe persecutions and executions of Manicheans and Christians in an effort to maintain and support the Roman state religion. * [[Galerius]], Strong proponent of Roman Paganism. Thought to have been the primary driver behind the Diocletian persecutions of Manicheans and Christians in defense of Roman religion. * [[Porphyry (philosopher)|Porphyry]], Neo-platonist philosopher who argued strongly in favor of Roman Paganism as opposed to the rise of Christianity in his day. Also wrote many treatises on Roman Paganism and is attributed as the author of many more that are of more uncertain origin. * [[Iamblichus of Chalcis]], disciple of Porphyry * [[Ammianus Marcellinus]], 4th-century historian * [[Maurus Servius Honoratus]], 4th-century grammarian * [[Julian the Apostate|Julian]] (ruled 361–363), attempted to re-establish Roman paganism, initiating a "pagan revival" among a number of families of the Roman elite * [[Alypius of Antioch]] * [[Vettius Agorius Praetextatus]] (d.384) * [[Virius Nicomachus Flavianus]] (334–394) * [[Quintus Aurelius Symmachus]] (c. 340–c. 402), Roman senator who attempted to have the altar of [[Altar of Victory]] restored * [[Hypatia of Alexandria]], neoplatonist philosopher, mathematician and astronomer, killed in 415 by a Christian mob * [[Nicomachus Flavianus (son)|Nicomachus Flavianus]] (d. after 432) * [[Eunapius]], last Hierophant of Eleusis * [[Martianus Capella]], 5th-century author * [[Proclus]] (d. 485), Neoplatonist philosopher * [[Zosimus]] (5th century) Byzantine historian * [[Damascius]], "the last of the Neoplatonists", (ca. 480–died after 533) * [[Gemistus Pletho]] (15th century) Byzantine philosopher
===Slavic=== Christianization of the [[Slavs]] took place in the 9th to 11th centuries, with a [[pagan reaction in Poland]] in the 1030s and conversion of the [[Polabian Slavs]] by the 1180s (see [[Wendish Crusade]]). *[[Porga of Croatia]] (d. 660), last pagan ruler of the [[Principality of Dalmatian Croatia]]. *[[Vlastimir of Serbia]] (d.851), last pagan ruler of the [[Principality of Serbia (medieval)|first Serbian principality]]. *[[Presian I of Bulgaria]] (d. 852), last pagan ruler of the [[Bulgarian Empire]]. *[[Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] (d. 972) *[[Yaropolk I of Kiev]] (d. 980), last pagan ruler of the [[Kievan Rus]] *[[Mstivoj]] (d. 995), leader of the Slavic revolt against [[Otto II, Holy Roman Emperor]]. *[[Niklot]] (d. 1160), leader of the [[Obotrites]].
==Modern==
=== Baltic === * [[Ernests Brastiņš|Brastiņš, Ernests]], founder of the neopagan organization [[Dievturība]]. * [[Valdis Celms|Celms, Valdis]], leader of the neopagan organization [[Dievturība|Latvijas Dievtuŗu sadraudze]]. * [[Jonas Trinkūnas|Trinkūnas, Jonas]], founder and the former high priest of the Lithuanian pagan society [[Romuva (religion)|Romuva]], husband of Inija Trinkūnienė. * [[Inija Trinkūnienė|Trinkūnienė, Inija]], current high priestess of the Lithuanian pagan society Romuva, wife of Jonas Trinkūnas.
===Germanic Neopaganism=== [[Germanic Neopaganism|Germanic Neopagans]] include: <!-- Only self-described Pagans are to be listed! Do not add yourself or people without Wikipedia articles to this list.-->
*[[Heinrich Himmler]] Second-in-command of the [[Third Reich]] and Reichsfuhrer of the [[Schutzstaffel]]. See [[Ideology of the SS]] for more information. *[[Sveinbjörn Beinteinsson|Beinteinsson, Sveinbjörn]], [[Íslenska Ásatrúarfélagið]] *[[Else Christensen|Christensen, Else]], [[Odinist Fellowship (United States)|Odinist Fellowship]] *[[Haukur Halldórsson]], Íslenska Ásatrúarfélagið *[[Heimgest]], [[Odinic Rite]] *[[Hilmar Örn Hilmarsson]], Íslenska Ásatrúarfélagið *[[Koenraad Logghe|Logghe,Koenraad]] *[[Alexander Rud Mills|Mills, Alexander Rud]], [[Odinism]] *[[Stephen McNallen|McNallen, Stephen]], [[Asatru Folk Assembly]] *[[Diana Paxson|Paxson, Diana]], science fiction author, editor of ''Idunna'', the quarterly journal of [[The Troth]] *[[Dylan and Cole Sprouse|Sprouse, Dylan]], actor, ''[[The Suite Life of Zack & Cody]]''<ref>[https://twitter.com/dylansprouse/status/436954047418232832 Dylan Sprouse on Twitter]</ref> *[[Varg Vikernes|Vikernes, Varg]], musician and writer. *[[Géza von Neményi|von Neményi, Géza]], [[Germanische Glaubens-Gemeinschaft]]
===Neo-druidism=== {{Further|List of druids and neo-druids}} [[Neo-druidism|Neo-druids]] include: <!-- Only self-described Pagans are to be listed! Do not add yourself or people without Wikipedia articles to this list.-->
* [[Isaac Bonewits|Bonewits, Isaac]], author and scholar of several Druid and neopagan related books and articles * [[Philip Carr-Gomm|Carr-Gomm, Philip]], current head of the Order of Bards, Ovates, and Druids. * [[Ronald Hutton|Hutton, Ronald]], scholar of British history; professor at University of Bristol, and author of books on the history of Neopaganism. * [[Arthur Uther Pendragon|Pendragon, Arthur]], leader of the Loyal Arthurian Warband, self-declared reincarnation of King Arthur. * [[Ross Nichols|Nichols, Ross]], founder of the Order of Bards, Ovates, and Druids. * [[Emma Restall Orr|Restall Orr, Emma]], Druid priestess, author, founder of the Druid Network. * [[Philip Shallcrass|Shallcrass, Philip]], current head of the British Druid Order.
===Wicca=== [[Wicca]]ns include: <!-- Only self-described Pagans are to be listed! Do not add yourself or people without Wikipedia articles to this list.-->
* [[Margot Adler|Adler, Margot]], author, journalist, Wiccan Priestess and Elder, [[National Public Radio]] correspondent in [[New York, New York|New York City]]. * [[Gael Baudino|Baudino, Gael]], author, mostly fantasy ([[Dianic Wicca]]n). * [[Paul Beyerl|Beyerl, Paul]], founder of [[The Rowan Tree Church]]. * [[Gavin Bone|Bone, Gavin]], Wiccan author and lecturer. * [[Raymond Buckland|Buckland, Raymond]], author of ''Buckland's Complete Book of Witchcraft'' and many others, and founder of [[Seax-Wica]]. * [[Z. Budapest|Budapest, Z.]], Pagan teacher writer etc. (Dianic Wicca). * [[Laurie Cabot|Cabot, Laurie]], official witch of Salem, author of ''[[Power of the Witch]]'' and ''[[Love Magic]]''. * [[Del Close|Close, Del]], considered one of the premier influences on modern [[improvisational theater]]. * [[Scott Cunningham|Cunningham, Scott]], author of ''Wicca: A Guide for the Solitary Practitioner'' and over 30 other titles on Wicca and other pagan religions. * [[Gerina Dunwich|Dunwich, Gerina]], author of ''[[Wicca Craft]]'' and other books on the details of spellwork * [[Sully Erna|Erna, Sully]], lead singer of [[Godsmack]] * [[Cerridwen Fallingstar|Fallingstar, Cerridwen]], author of ''The Heart of the Fire'' * [[Janet Farrar|Farrar, Janet]], author * [[Stewart Farrar|Farrar, Stewart]], author * [[LaSara Firefox|Firefox, LaSara]], author * [[Gavin Frost|Frost, Gavin]] and [[Yvonne Frost|Frost, Yvonne]], founders of the [[Church and School of Wicca]] * [[Yasmine Galenorn|Galenorn, Yasmine]], author of ''[[Embracing the Moon]]'' and ''[[Dancing the Sun]]'' * [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gardner, Gerald]], founder of modern Wicca * [[Raven Grimassi|Grimassi, Raven]], author on ''[[Stregheria]]'' and family witchcraft * [[Fiona Horne|Horne, Fiona]], author of ''[[Witch: A Personal Journey]]'' and other books on Wicca * [[Inkubus Sukkubus]], musical group * [[Deborah Lipp|Lipp, Deborah]], author of books on Wicca * [[Monica Mayhem|Mayhem, Monica]], Australian author, singer, model, actress and retired pornographic actress * [[Patrick McCollum|McCollum, Patrick]], Wiccan prison chaplain * [[Stanley Modrzyk|Modrzyk, Stanley]], author of books on Wicca * [[Omnia (band)|Omnia]], musical group * [[Christopher Penczak|Penczak, Christopher]], author of ''Gay Witchcraft'' and the ''[[Inner Temple (book series)|Inner Temple]]'' series. * [[Carol Queen|Queen, Carol]], author, editor, sociologist and sexologist * [[Silver Ravenwolf|Ravenwolf, Silver]], controversial Wiccan author and contributor to the New Generation of Wicca and part of the Black Forest Clan. * [[Alex Sanders (Wiccan)|Sanders, Alex]], founder of the [[Alexandrian Wicca|Alexandrian]] tradition of Wicca. * [[Maxine Sanders|Sanders, Maxine]], co-founder of the [[Alexandrian Wicca|Alexandrian]] tradition * [[Doreen Valiente|Valiente, Doreen]], author and contemporary of Gardner * [[Phyllis Curott|Curott, Phyllis]], shamanic Wiccan. Founder of the tradition of Ara and author of the books: ''Book of Shadows'', ''WitchCrafting'', and ''The Love Spell''.
===Various or unspecified=== Unspecified Neopagans include: <!-- Only self-described Pagans are to be listed! Do not add people without Wikipedia articles to this list. The article linked needs to contain a referenced statement on the subject's religion --> * [[Rae Beth|Beth, Rae]], author of ''Hedgewitch'' and noted [[tarot]] reader * [[Granny Boswell|Boswell, Granny]], notable [[Cornwall|Cornish]] [[witch]] * [[Selena Fox|Fox, Selena]], one of the founders of [[Circle Sanctuary]] * [[Marian Green|Green, Marian]], author, founder of [[Quest Conference]] and journal, former editor of [[Pagan Dawn]] and former member of the [[Pagan Federation]] Council. * [[Paul Huson|Huson, Paul]], author of ''[[Mastering Witchcraft]]'', ''Mystical Origins of the Tarot'', and other titles. * [[Patricia Kennealy-Morrison|Kennealy-Morrison, Patricia]] – [[Celtic polytheism|Celtic Pagan]] high priestess, [[music criticism|rock critic]], author of ''[[The Keltiad]]'' series of [[science fiction]]/[[fantasy fiction|fantasy]] novels, and ''Strange Days – My Life With and Without [[Jim Morrison]]'' * [[Sharon Knight|Knight, Sharon]], [[Celtic music|Celtic]] / [[Rock music|Rock]] [[musician]], songwriter, producer; front person of the [[Pagan Rock]] band [[Sharon Knight|Pandemonaeon]]; [[Feri]] initiate * [[Leo Martello]] * [[Fernando Pessoa|Pessoa, Fernando]], Portuguese writer * [[Raimonds Vējonis|Vējonis, Raimonds]], president of [[Latvia]]<ref>[http://www.lsm.lv/en/article/politics/latvia-provides-eus-first-green-president-raimonds-vejonis.a132316/ Latvia provides EU«s first »green' president - Raimonds Vējonis]. [[Public Broadcasting of Latvia]] "He is married with two children and lists his religious views as “pagan” on his Facebook page."</ref> * [[Eric Steven Raymond|Raymond, Eric Steven]], programmer and author of ''The Hacker's Dictionary'' and ''How to Be a Hacker'' * [[Starhawk]], [[activist]], [[anarchist]] and author of ''[[Spiral Dance (book)|The Spiral Dance]]'', ''[[Dreaming the Dark]]'', ''[[Webs of Power]]'', etc.; one of the original members of the [[Reclaiming (neopaganism)|Reclaiming Collective]]. * [[Oberon Zell-Ravenheart]], [[Church of All Worlds]] * [[Morning Glory Zell-Ravenheart]], [[Church of All Worlds]] * [[Ra Un Nefer Amen]], [[Kemetism]] * [[Paolo Rustichelli]], composer (eclectic)
==See also== * [[List of druids and neo-druids]] * [[List of Neopagan movements]] * [[Lists of people by belief]]

revision.text:
This is a list of notable persons who have been members of the [[United States Peace Corps]], along with their terms of service. Those listed on this page should meet Wikipedia's [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Notability_(people)#Basic_criteria basic criteria for notability]. The [[:Category:Peace Corps volunteers|Peace Corps volunteers category]] page may include a more extensive list of individuals.
== Business ==
* [[Patricia Cloherty]], Chairman and CEO, Delta Private Equity Partners, former Chairman of The U.S. Russia Investment Fund, Deputy Administration for the U.S. Small Business Administration (Brazil 1963-65) * [[Reed Hastings]], founder and CEO of Netflix (Swaziland 1983–85) * [[Michael McCaskey]], chairman of the board, Chicago Bears (Ethiopia 1965–67) * [[Bob Haas]], Chairman Emeritus of Levi Strauss & Co., son of Walter A. Haas Jr., and the great-great-grandnephew of the company's founder, Levi Strauss (Ivory Coast 1964–66) * [[Alberto Ibargüen]], President and CEO of the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation (Venezuela, 1966–68)
== Journalists == * [[T. D. Allman]], journalist/author (Vanity Fair; New Yorker; NYT) (Nepal, 1966–68) * [[Peter Hessler]], author of River Town: Two Years on the Yangtze; Oracle Bones; Country Driving. Staff writer, New Yorker ([[China]] 1996–97) * [[Roger K. Lewis]], Washington Post columnist, architect, author, cartoonist (Tunisia, 1964–66) * [[Maureen Orth]], journalist, author, and a Special Correspondent for Vanity Fair magazine (Colombia, 1964–66) * [[George Packer]], journalist, novelist, and playwright. He is best known for his writings for The New Yorker about U.S. foreign policy and for his book The Assassins' Gate: America in Iraq (Togo 1982–1983) * [[Ben Bradlee Jr.]], journalist and writer. He was a reporter and editor at The Boston Globe for 25 years (Afghanistan 1970–1972) * [[Tony D'Souza]], novelist, journalist, essayist, reviewer, travel and short story writer (India 1966-1968, Côte d'Ivoire 2001–2002) * [[Leon Dash]], Pulitzer Prize winning reporter for the Washington Post (Kenya 1969–1970) * [[Arnold Hano]], editor, novelist, biographer and journalist, best known for his non-fiction work, A Day in the Bleachers, frequent contributor to such publications as The New York Times, Sport, Sports Illustrated, and TV Guide (Costa Rica 1991–1993) * [[Laurence Leamer]], associate editor at Newsweek anc contributor to Harper's, The New York Times Magazine, and Playboy (Nepal 1964–1966)
== Literature and Non-fiction == * [[Mildred D. Taylor]], [[African-American]] writer known for her works exploring the struggle faced by African-American families in the [[Deep South]] (Ethiopia 1965–67) * [[Kent Haruf]], author of Plainsong, The Tie That Binds, Where You Once Belonged, Eventide, Benediction, Our Souls at Night ([[Turkey]] 1966–68) * [[Paul Theroux]], author of [[Mosquito Coast]] and Great Railway Bazaar ([[Malawi]] 1963–65) * [[Mildred D. Taylor|Mildred Taylor]], author of Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry, winner of [[Newbery Award]] ([[Ethiopia]] 1965–67) * [[Roland Merullo]], author of ''Leaving Losapas'', ''In Revere, In Those Days'', ''Breakfast with Buddha'', ([[Micronesia]] 1979–1980) * [[Bob Shacochis]], author of Easy in the Island, winner of the [[American Book Award]] (Eastern Caribbean 1975–76) * [[Moritz Thomsen]], author of ''Living Poor'' ([[Ecuador]] 1963–65) * [[Richard Wiley]], author of Ahmed's Revenge and Soldiers in Hiding, winner of PEN/Faulkner Award (Korea 1967–69) * [[Howard Ashman]], American playwright and lyricist (Burkina Faso ? – ?) * [[George B. Hutchinson]], Author of In Search of Nella Larsen (Burkina Faso 1975–1977) * [[Charles Murray (political scientist)|Charles Murray]], American libertarian political scientist, author, and columnist. Well known for Losing Ground: American Social Policy 1950–1980 and his controversial book The Bell Curve (Thailand 1965–1968) * [[John Perkins (author)|John Perkins]], Author of Confessions of an Economic Hit Man (Ecuador 1968–1970) * [[Mark T. Sullivan]], author who writes mystery and suspense novels with James Patterson (Niger ?–?)
== Art ==
* [[Martin Puryear]], sculptor (Sierra Leone 1964–1966) * [[Wayne Chabre]], sculptor (Lesotho 1969–1970) * [[Joel Shapiro]], sculptor ([[India]] 1965–67)
== Music ==
* [[Kinky Friedman]], Texas singer, songwriter, novelist, politician (Malaysia 1967–1969) * [[Mary Kim Joh]], Korean-American music composer, academic and medical research scientist. (Liberia 1977–78)<ref name="dunning">Dunning, Jennifer. [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/11/obituaries/11joh.html?_r=0 "Mary Kim Joh, 101, Who Wrote a Korean Anthem, Is Dead,"] ''New York Times.'' February 11, 2005; retrieved 2012-12-14.</ref>
== Television, Film, Theater, and Radio ==
* [[Chris Matthews]], host of NBC's Hardball (Swaziland 1968–70) * [[Bob Vila]], Host of Television show "This Old House" (Panama 1971–73) * [[Bob Beckel]], political analyst, Bob Beckel & Associates (Philippines 1971–72) * [[Taylor Hackford]], movie producer of Ray, An Officer and a Gentleman; and The Devil's Advocate ([[Bolivia]] 1968–69) * [[Chyna|Joanie Laurer]] (chyna), American professional wrestler, glamour model, pornographic film actress, and bodybuilder. (Costa Rica 1993–95) * [[Richard Sanders (actor)|Richard Sanders]], actor best known for playing [[Les Nessman]] on ''[[WKRP in Cincinnati]]'' ([[Brazil]] 1966–69) * [[Marco Werman]], Werman is the host of Public Radio International's The World (Togo, 1984–87) * [[Marissa Aroy]], Filipino-American director and producer. She directed the documentaries Sikhs in America ( Dominican Republic 1995–1997) * [[Rajiv Joseph]], American playwright and a 2010 Pulitzer Prize finalist (senegal 1996-1998) * [[Milt Kogan]], actor (Upper Volta 1970–1972)
== Activism and Aid ==
* [[Ken Hackett]], president, Catholic Relief Services and former United States Ambassador to the Holy See (Ghana 1968–1971) * [[Sapreet Kaur]], civil rights activist and executive director of the Sikh Coalition (Uganda, 1998–2001) * [[Cindy Marano]], economic justice and women's rights activist (Ecuador 1967–1969) * [[Carl Pope (environmentalist)|Carl Pope]], former Executive Director of the Sierra Club (India 1967 – 1969) * [[Gregory Stanton]], He is the founder and president of Genocide Watch, the founder and director of the Cambodian Genocide Project, and the founder and Chair of the International Campaign to End Genocide (Ivory Coast ?–?)
==Government== * [[M. Peter McPherson]], served as a special assistant to President Gerald Ford, administrator of USAID (Peru 1965–1966) * [[Timothy Kraft]], retired political consultant; [[campaign manager]] in [[U.S. presidential election, 1980|1980]] for [[U.S. President]] [[Jimmy Carter]] (Guatemala 1963-64) * [[John T. Morton]], Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) 2009–2013 (Chad ?–?) * [[Peter Navarro]], American heterodox economist, who currently serves as the Assistant to the President, Director of Trade and Industrial Policy, and the Director of the White House National Trade Council (Thailand 1973–1976) * [[Robert Pastor]], member of the National Security Council (Malaysia 1970–72)
=== Elected Office ===
* [[Christopher Dodd]], Former U.S. Senator, Connecticut (Dominican Republic 1966–68) * [[Jim Doyle]], Governor of Wisconsin and wife Jessica Doyle (Tunisia 1967–69) * [[Steve Driehaus]], U.S. Representative from Ohio (Senegal 1988–1990) * [[Sam Farr]], U.S. Representative from California (Colombia 1964–66) * [[John Garamendi]], State of California Insurance Commissioner, US Congressman from California (Ethiopia 1966–68) * [[Tony P. Hall]], Former US Congressman from Ohio, Former Ambassador to the FAO (Thailand 1966–67) * [[Joseph P. Kennedy III]], U.S. Representative from Massachusetts (Dominican Republic 2004–2006) * [[Tom Murphy (mayor)|Thomas Murphy, Jr.]], mayor of the City of Pittsburgh, PA (Paraguay 1970–72) * [[Thomas Petri]], U.S. Representative from Wisconsin (Somalia 1966–67) * [[Michael A. Rice]], Rhode Island State Representative (Philippines 1981–85) * [[Christopher Shays]], former U.S. Representative from Connecticut (Fiji 1968–70) * [[Bob Taft]], served as governor of Ohio from 1999 to 2007. (Tanzania 1963–65) * [[Paul Tsongas]] Former US Senator, candidate for President in 1992 (Ethiopia 1962-64) * [[James T. Walsh|James Walsh]], former U.S. Representative from New York (Nepal 1970–72) * [[Mike Ward (American politician)|Mike Ward]], former U.S. Representative from Kentucky (The Gamiba 1978–79) * [[Paul B. Henry]], former U.S. Representative from Michigan (Liberia and Ethiopia 1963–1965) * [[Tom Wolf]], 47th and current Governor of Pennsylvania, (India ? – ?) * [[Jason Carter (politician)|Jason Carter]] Lawyer and politician from the state of Georgia. Carter is a former state senator and was the Democratic nominee for Georgia governor (South Africa 1997–99) * [[Chris Beutler]], Mayor of Lincoln, Nebraska (Turkey 1966–1967) * [[Jim Courter]], Former U.S. Representatives from New Jersey (Venezuela 1967 – 1969) * [[Thomas J. Murphy Jr.]], former mayor of Pittsburgh (Paraguay ?–?) * [[Kitty Piercy]], Mayor of Eugene, Oregon (ethiopia 1964–1966) * [[Rodger Randle]], former mayor of Tulsa, Oklahoma (Brazil 1962–1964)
=== Peace Corps Directors ===
* [[Aaron S. Williams]], former Peace Corps Director, (Dominican Republic, 1967–70) * [[Ron Tschetter]], 17th Director of The Peace Corps (India 1966–68) * [[Carol Bellamy]], former Peace Corps Director, former head of UNESCO, president of World Learning (Guatemala 1963–1965) * [[Mark L. Schneider|Mark Schneider]], former Peace Corps Director, senior vice president of International Crisis Group (El Salvador 1966–68) * [[Carrie Hessler-Radelet]], the 19th Director of the Peace Corps, (Western Samoa 1981–1984) * [[Mark L. Schneider]], The 15th Director of the Peace Corps, (El Salvador) * [[Carol Bellamy]], 13th Director of the Peace Corps, (Guatemala 1963 – 1965) * [[Aaron S. Williams]], 18th Director of the Peace Corps, (Dominican Republic 1967–1970)
=== Law === * [[Drew S. Days III]], served as United States Solicitor General from 1993 to 1996 under President Bill Clinton and first African American Assistant Attorney General for the Civil Rights Division in the Carter Administration from 1977 to 1980 (Honduras 1967–69) * [[James P. Gray]], American jurist and writer. Presiding judge of the Superior Court of Orange County, California and vice presidential nominee for the libertarian party in 2012 (Costa Rica 1966 – 1968.) * [[Sarah Parker]], Chief Justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court (Turkey 1964–1966)
=== Foreign service ===
* [[Christopher R. Hill]], American diplomat who served as the U.S. Ambassador to Iraq from 2009 to 2010 (Cameroon 1974–76) * [[Vicki Huddleston]], ambassador to Mali and Madagascar, Charge de affaires to Haiti and Ethiopia, and Principal Officer to the US Interests Section in Havana (Peru 1964–66) * [[Darryl N. Johnson]], ambassador to Thailand (Thailand 1962–65) * [[Kathleen Stephens]], ambassador to South Korea (South Korea, 1975–77) * [[Victor L. Tomseth]], ambassador to Laos and hostage in the [[Iran hostage crisis]] * [[Richard Boucher]], American diplomat who was Deputy Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) from 2009 until 2013 (Senegal, 1973–75) * [[Robert Blackwill]], United States Ambassador to India , and United States National Security Council Deputy for Iraq (Malawi 1964 – 1966) * [[Gina Abercrombie-Winstanley]], diplomat who served as U.S. Ambassador to Malta (oman ? – ?) * [[Charles C. Adams Jr.]], former United States Ambassador to Finland, (Kenya 1968 – 1970) * [[Frank Almaguer]], served as United States Ambassador to Honduras (Belize 1967–1969) * [[Michael R. Arietti]], United States ambassador to the nation of Rwanda (India ?–?) * [[Michael Corbin]], United States Ambassador to the United Arab Emirates (Mauritania 1982–1984) * [[Joseph R. Donovan Jr.]], diplomat and the current United States Ambassador to Indonesia (Korea ?–?) * [[Laurence Foley]], American diplomat who was assassinated outside his home in Amman, Jordan. * [[Gordon Gray III]], Minister-Counselor and former U.S. Ambassador to Tunisia (Morocco 1978–1980) * [[Edmund Hull]], United States Ambassador to Yemen (Tunisia, 1987–1990) * [[John Limbert]], former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Iran (Iran 1964–1966) * [[Stephen Schwartz (diplomat)|Stephen Schwartz]] United States Ambassador to Somalia (Cameroon 1981–1983) * [[J. Christopher Stevens]], former U.S. Ambassador to Libya (Morocco 1983–1985)
== Education ==
* [[James H. Fowler]], American social scientist specializing in social networks, cooperation, political participation, and genopolitics (Ecuador, 1992–1994) * [[Victor H. Mair]], American Sinologist and professor of Chinese at the University of Pennsylvania (Nepal 1965–1967) * [[Suzanne Blier|Suzanne Preston Blier]], Allen Whitehill Clowes Professor of Fine Arts and of African and African American Studies, Harvard University (Benin 1969–71) * [[Allan Gibbard]], Richard B. Brandt Distinguished University Professor of Philosophy at the University of Michigan (Ghana 1963–65) * [[Clark Gibson]], Professor of Political Science, [[University of California, San Diego]] (Nepal) * [[Roger K. '''Advocates of [[animal rights]]''' as well as activists for [[Animal Liberation (book)|animal liberation]] hold the view that to deny the most basic needs of [[sentient]] creatures—such as the avoidance of pain—to non-human animals, on the basis of species membership alone, is a form of discrimination akin to racism or sexism. Many animal rights advocates argue that non-human animals should be regarded as persons and members of the moral community whose interests deserve legal protection.<ref>Taylor, Angus. ''Animals and Ethics: An Overview of the Philosophical Debate''. Broadview Press, 2003, p. 15ff.</ref>
The animal rights movement emerged in the 19th century, focused largely on opposition to [[vivisection]], and in the 1960s the modern movement sprang up in England around the [[Hunt Saboteurs Association]]. In the 1970s, the Australian and American philosophers, [[Peter Singer]] and [[Tom Regan]], began to provide the movement with its philosophical foundations. Singer argued for animal liberation on the basis of [[utilitarianism]], first in 1973 in ''The New York Review of Books'' and later in his ''[[Animal Liberation (book)|Animal Liberation]]'' (1975), while Regan developed a [[Deontology|deontological]] theory of animal rights in several papers from 1975 onwards, followed by ''The Case for Animal Rights'' (1983).<ref>Finsen, Susan and Finsen, Lawrence. "Animal rights movement," in Marc Bekoff (ed.). ''The Encyclopedia of Animal Rights and Animal Welfare''. Greenwood, 2009. *For more about the history of the ideas, see Kean, Hilda. ''Animal Rights: Political and Social Change in Britain since 1800''. Reaktion Books, 1998. *Also see: :*Singer, Peter. [http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1973/apr/05/animal-liberation/ "Animal liberation"], ''The New York Review of Books'', Volume 20, Number 5, 5 April 1973. :*[http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1973/jun/14/food-for-thought/ "Food for Thought"], letter from David Rosinger and a reply from Peter Singer, ''The New York Review of Books'', Volume 20, Number 10, 14 June 1973. :*Singer, Peter. ''Animal Liberation'' New York Review/Random House, 1975. :*Regan, Tom. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/40230566 "The Moral Basis of Vegetarianism"], ''Canadian Journal of Philosophy'', Vol. 5, No. 2 (Oct., 1975), pp. 181-214. :*Regan, Tom. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2219017 "McCloskey on Why Animals Cannot Have Rights"], ''The Philosophical Quarterly'', Vol. 26, No. 104 (Jul., 1976), pp. 251-257. :*Regan, Tom. ''The Case for Animal Rights''. University of California Press, 1983.</ref>
A distinction persists within the movement—based on the utilitarian/deontological divide—between those who seek incremental reform, a position known as [[animal protectionism]], and those on the [[Abolitionism (animal rights)|abolitionist]] side, who argue that reform that aims to regulate, rather than abolish, the property status of animals is counter-productive.<ref>Francione, Gary L. and Garner, Robert. ''The Animal Rights Debate: Abolition or Regulation?''. Columbia University Press, 2010, p. 1ff, 103ff.</ref>
Historically speaking it could well be argued that the genesis of the Animal Rights movement was truly in India given the impact that both Buddhism and Jainism had on people in India and the neighbouring countries in Asia. The largest number and highest percentage of Vegetarians per population for any country is in India. Buddhism among the global religions is an animal rights religion par excellence. It has long subscribed to the belief that all life forms including that of non-human animals are sacred and deserving of respect, and extolls kindness and compassion as utmost virtues worthy of cultivation. Buddhism unreservedly embraces all living beings in its ethical [[cosmology]] without discrimination on grounds of species, race, or creed. Buddhist tenets—including the first precept, “Do not kill”—extend to both human and non-human sentient beings. The Buddha was so adamant and protective of the more vulnerable members of the moral community—namely the animals—that he declared that: “He who has laid aside the cudgel that injures any creature whether moving or still, who neither slays nor causes to be slain—him I call an Arya (Noble person)” (Dhammapada).

{{Infobox Radio Show | show_name=The Mark Williams Show | italic_title=no | image = | imagesize = | caption = | format = [[Talk radio|Talk]] | starring = Mark Williams | country = United States | website = [http://www.talkermark.com The Mark Williams Show] }} '''Mark Williams''' is an American Constitutional activist, radio talk show host and author based in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[California]]. He is the author of ''It's Not Right Versus Left, It's Right Versus Wrong; Exposing the Socialist Agenda'' and ''Taking Back America One Tea Party at a Time''.
==Career== Mark Williams is a native of [[Attleboro, Massachusetts]] and began his career by starting a radio station in the local high school in 1973.
Williams' first commercial radio job was as a salesman at the former [[WPEP]] in Taunton, Massachusetts. He then had an over night talk show on [[WSAR]] (Fall River, Massachusetts). He later was an executive producer position at Boston's [[WRKO]] AM. He arrived in Sacramento ([[KFBK (AM)|KFBK]] AM) in 2000 after on-air stints in San Diego ([[XETRA-AM|XTRA]] AM); Tampa ([[WFLA (AM)|WFLA]] AM); Dayton, Ohio ([[WHIO (AM)|WHIO]] AM); and the Capital District of New York ([[WGY (AM)|WGY]]).
In 2005 he and his wife/producer, Holly Williams, and Melanie Morgan of [[KSFO]] traveled to Iraq and broadcast from various locations around Baghdad, shows for which each were awarded the Mark Twain Award by the [[Associated Press Radio and Television Association]],<ref>[http://www.thesunchronicle.com/articles/2006/02/20/city/city4.txt AHS grad's views earn him top ratings in Calif. - The Sun Chronicle Online - City<!-- Bot generated title -->]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and two Greater Bay Area Journalism Awards.<ref>[http://sfppc.blogspot.com/2006/06/2006-greater-bay-area-journalism-awards.html San Francisco Peninsula Press Club: 2006 Greater Bay Area Journalism Awards<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Williams served as the spokesperson for the [[Tea Party Express]], resigning in July, 2010, amid controversy over an entry he posted to his blog.<ref name="Memoli2010">{{cite news | last1 = Memoli | first1 = Michael | last2 = Hennessey | first2 = Kathleen | date = July 24, 2010 | title = Tea Party Express spokesman resigns after racist blog post | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | url = http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jul/24/nation/la-na-tea-party-20100724 | accessdate = September 4, 2011 }}</ref> The post included a "mock letter to Abraham Lincoln from NAACP President Benjamin Jealous" in which he used racially charged language to respond to the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|NAACP]]'s stance against racist elements within the [[Tea Party movement]]. The [[National Tea Party Federation]] called it an embarrassment, and ousted the Tea Party Express from its organisation after they refused to fire Williams.<ref name="Memoli2010" /><ref name="NYDailyNews">{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2010/07/18/2010-07-18_tea_party_express_leader_mark_williams_expelled_over_colored_people_letter.html |title=Tea Party Express leader Mark Williams kicked out over 'Colored People' letter |date=2010-07-18 |work=[[New York Daily News]] |last=Kennedy |first=Helen}} </ref> Williams has been an opponent of the [[Park51]] project to build an Islamic community center in [[Lower Manhattan]]. Due to its proximity to the [[World Trade Center site]], he dubbed it the "Ground Zero" mosque and called it a ''"temple to terrorists,"'' saying, ''"The monument would consist of a Mosque for the worship of the terrorists' monkey-god."''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/19/2010-05-19_tea_party_leader_mark_williams_says_muslims_worship_a_monkey_god_blasts_ground_z.html|title=Tea Party leader Mark Williams says Muslims worship a 'monkey god', blasts Ground Zero mosque|last=Hutchinson|first=Bill|date=May 19, 2010|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|accessdate=19 July 2010}}</ref> Williams' comments drew rebukes from New York City Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]], New York State Senators and [[Muslim]] leaders. Williams later wrote, "I owe an apology to millions of Hindus who worship Lord [[Hanuman]], an actual Monkey God. Hanuman is worshiped as a symbol of perseverance, strength, and devotion ... Those are hardly the traits of whatever the Hell (literally) it is that terrorists worship." When questioned by ''The Washington Post'' about his comments about [[Islam]] and Obama, Williams has claimed the controversy has "been fantastic for the movement".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/05/20/2010-05-20_tea_party_leader_mark_williams_says_sorry_for_monkey_god_remark__to_hindus.html|title=Tea Party Express leader Mark Williams says 'sorry' – to Hindus – for slamming Muslim's 'monkey god' |publisher=NY Daily News |date=May 20, 2010|accessdate=June 13, 2010 |location=New York |first=Samuel |last=Goldsmith}}</ref><ref>[http://voices.washingtonpost.com/right-now/2010/05/mark_williams_the_monkey_god_a.html Mark Williams, the monkey god and the 'controversy' game]; ''Washington Post''; May 20, 2010</ref>
Williams was featured in Dinesh D'Sousa's 2012 film biography of Obama "2016: Obama's America" a segment where Williams appears on CNN's Anderson Cooper show.

{{one source|date=September 2011}} '''Mehmed-''beg'' Kulenović''', '''''Gazi'' Mehmed-''beg'' Kulenović''', '''Mehmed-''beg'' Kulinović''', also known as '''Kulin-''kapetan''''' (1776–13 August 1806) was a [[Bosnians|Bosnian]] [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] soldier born and raised in [[Bihać]] and later became the Kapetan of [[Bosnia Eyalet]]. He was a very important regional official for the Ottoman forces due to his ties with the aristocracy in [[Belgrade]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Ime (neophodno) |url=http://ljutoc.wordpress.com/2010/04/15/kulin-kapetan/ |title=Mehmed-beg Kulenović (Kulinović)-Kulin-kapetan « Ljutočka Dolina |publisher=Ljutoc.wordpress.com |date=2010-04-15 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> He was killed in the [[First Serbian Uprising]].
==Early life== Mehmed-''beg'' Kulenović was the son of ''Hadži''-Ibrahim-''beg'' Kulenović of [[Kulen Vakuf]]. He soon entered Ottoman service and became one of the most important military frontier authorities in [[Bosnia Eyalet]], he was referred to by his servicemen as the "Master of [[Ostrovica Castle|Ostrovica]]". He participated in several military campaigns starting with the assistance of ''Abu Bekir Pasha of [[Belgrade]]'', he also attempted to subdue with the aim of calming the Serbian revolt against Belgrade ''Dahia'' (renegade [[Janissary]]). But later defended the populace of [[Višegrad|Visegrad]] from Serbian insurgents. He guarded the borders of the Bosnia Eyalet on the [[Drina]] and in the summer 1806, he accompanied an Ottoman battalion that was defeated during the [[Battle of Mišar]].
==First Serbian Uprising and Battle of Mišar== When the [[First Serbian Uprising]] broke out in 1804–05, after the assassination of [[Hadji Mustafa Pasha]] of Belgrade, turmoil had become evident throughout the [[Sanjak of Smederevo]]; thousands of Muslim refugees from the Sanjak began to pour into the [[Sanjak of Zvornik]]. In 1805 the Serbian rebels led by [[Luka Lazarević]] had begun their assault on Zvornik itself prompting the Ottoman [[Grand Vizier]] to mobilize his army in the Bosnia Eyalet commanded by [[Sulejman-paša Skopljak]] and Mehmed-beg Kulenović.
Kulenović guarded the borders of the Bosnia Eyalet on the [[Drina]] and in the summer of 1806 accompanied an Ottoman battalion led by Sulejman-paša that was on its way to Mišar. For months the Serbian rebels remained entrenched in different strongholds throughout and nearby the Mišar Hill and a pitched battle itself seemed impossible for the Serbian rebels. Mehmed-beg Kulenović and the remaining Ottoman Bosnian troops continued asymmetric efforts against the advancements of the Serbians. Kulenović's efforts were bold enough to cause Luka Lazarević to request for a cavalry challenge. But Kulenović remained with his army and was killed by Serbian rebel musket-fire, while fighting in the woods. Mehmed-beg Kulenović was wounded and then died from wounds, and his body was transferred to Bosnia and buried in the graveyard of the mosque in [[Janja]]. The rebellion continued for years after his death.
