(2010–2014) | commands = | battles = | battles_label = | awards = [[File:Hero of Ukraine ribbon bar.png|23px|border]] [[Hero of Ukraine]]
[[File:Order for Bravery of Ukraine.png|40px|border]] [[Order For Courage]]{{citation news|url=https://ua.112.ua/suspilstvo/poroshenko-nagorodiv-lotchicyu-savchenko-ordenom-za-muzhnist-105913.html|script-title=uk:Порошенко нагородив льотчицю Савченко орденом "За мужність"|trans-title=Poroshenko awarded the pilot Savchenko with the "Order For Courage"|language=uk|work=112.UA|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=16 August 2017}} | memorials = | spouse = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = | website = | module = | office1 = [[File:Logo of the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine.svg|25px]] [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] | convocation1 = [[8th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|8th convocation]] | constituency1 = [[Batkivshchyna]], No.1{{cite web|title=People's Deputy of Ukraine of the VIII convocation|url=http://itd.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/page/18166|website=Official portal|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine]]|accessdate=22 December 2014|language=Ukrainian}} | term_start1 = 27 November 2014 | term_end1 = | president1 = [[Petro Poroshenko]] }} '''Nadiya Viktorivna Savchenko''' ({{lang-uk|Надія Вікторівна Савченко}}; born 11 May 1981) is a Ukrainian politician and former [[Army aviation]] pilot in the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces]]. [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] [[8th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|8th convocation]] from 27 November 2014.{{r|PACE}}{{cite web|url=http://itd.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/page/18166|title=Офіційний портал Верховної Ради України|website=itd.rada.gov.ua|accessdate=22 March 2018}} During the 2014 [[War in Donbass]] Savchenko, a [[lieutenant|first lieutenant]] in the Ukrainian Ground Forces, served as instructor with a volunteer infantry unit, the [[Aidar Battalion]]. In June 2014, she was captured by pro-Russian forces in eastern Ukraine{{r|rainOR}} and handed over to Russia where she was accused of having directed artillery fire that [[Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin|killed two Russian state-television journalists]] at the positions of pro-Russian forces in Ukraine.{{r|NewYorker-20160410}} She was subsequently charged and convicted of murder and illegally crossing Russian state border{{r|TASS-20141107}}{{r|BBC140709}}{{r|NBC140709}} despite being [[Kidnapping|abducted]] from Ukrainian territory one hour before the deaths of the journalists.According to version by the prosecution, the rebels who captured Savchenko let her go and she crossed Russian border, "[http://www.novayagazeta.ru/politics/72340.html I have right for everything]", by [[Novaya gazeta]]{{cite news|url=https://meduza.io/feature/2016/03/21/ya-ee-vzyal-i-lichno-peredal-plotnitskomu|title="Я ее взял и лично передал Плотницкому"|last=Azar|first=Iliya|date=21 March 2016|publisher=Meduza.io|language=Russian|accessdate=22 March 2016}} One of her lawyers, [[Mark Feygin]], said she was a [[prisoner-of-war]] and called on the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] and the [[United Nations]] to demand her immediate release and that of the other Ukrainian [[POW]]s lest Russia be held in violation of the [[Geneva Conventions]].{{r|WP141224}}{{r|NewYorker-20160410}} European Union ministers and their representative regarded her detention as illegal and that her trial did not respect basic [[human rights]], including the right to [[Fair procedure|fair proceedings]].{{r|EEAS-2016}} In November 2014, while still imprisoned, Savchenko was elected to the Verkhovna Rada in the [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], and she formally resigned from her military post.{{r|NSinRda714}}{{r|TASS-20141107}}{{r|NSsp221214}} On 25 May 2016, Savchencko was exchanged in a prisoner swap for Russian [[GRU]] officers{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/russian/russia/2016/05/160525_erofeev_aleksandrov_profile|script-title=ru:Ерофеев и Александров: на кого обменяли Савченко|trans-title=Erofeev and Alexandrov: who was exchanged for Savchenko|language=ru|publisher=Bbc.com|date=25 May 2016|accessdate=25 July 2017}} Yevgeny Yerofeyev and Alexander Alexandrov captured by Ukraine. After returning to Ukraine, Savchenko declared her intention to participate as a presidential candidate in [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2019]].[https://nation-news.ru/286679-savchenko-zayavila-chto-budet-uchastvovat-v-prezidentskih-vyborah-na-ukraine-v-2019-godu Savchenko said that she will participate in the presidential elections in Ukraine in 2019 (Russian)] However, she was arrested and charged with planning a terrorist attack to overthrow the Ukrainian government.[https://www.svoboda.org/a/29413524.html They planned to finish everyone off. The case of Nadezhda Savchenko almost reached the court (Russian)], by [[RFE/RL]] Savchenko was one of Ukraine's first women to train as a military aeroplane pilot, and is the only female aviator to pilot the [[Sukhoi Su-24]] bomber and the [[Mil Mi-24]] helicopter.{{r|Grani-NS}} == Life and military career == [[File:Nadiya Savchenko.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Savchenko is a Ukrainian military pilot and a former first lieutenant of the Ukrainian Air Force. She resigned after being elected as a member of the Ukrainian parliament.]] Nadiya Savchenko and her younger sister Vira were born in [[Kiev]] in the [[Troieshchyna]] neighbourhood. Their father was an agricultural engineer, their mother a designer and cargo manager.{{r|RFE140711}} Savchenko's father was a member of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] while her mother was an [[anti-communist]]. Her mother and sister Vira said in an interview that she and her sister were brought up in a Ukrainian-speaking household and attending Ukrainian-language schools.{{r|RFE140711}} At 16, Savchenko was already determined to become a pilot. She joined the Ukrainian Army, working as a radio operator with the country's railway forces before training as a paratrooper.{{r|RFE140711}} She was then the only Ukrainian female [[soldier]] in the (2004–2008) [[Multi-National Force – Iraq#2008 withdrawals|Ukrainian peacekeeping troops]] in [[Iraq]]. Upon returning, she successfully petitioned the [[Ministry of Defence (Ukraine)|Defence Ministry]] for the right to attend the prestigious Air Force University in [[Kharkiv]], which until then had been open only to men; she graduated in 2009.{{r|LP140628}} In 2010, she was posted to the [[3rd Army Aviation Regiment (Ukraine)|3rd Army Aviation Regiment]] in [[Brody]], [[Lviv Oblast]]. In 2011, the Ukraine Defence Forces published a 20-minute documentary about Savchenko and her military career.{{r|Youtube-6GWePLY1T-M}} She also featured in a [[United Nations]] Development Program as part of a drive to promote equality in the Ukrainian military.{{r|IBT140712}} Savchenko found her time in Brody boring and often got drunk. She was unhappy at being trained to fly the [[Mil Mi-24|Mi-24]] attack helicopter, instead of fast jets. Her former commanding officer at Brody, Edward Zahurskiy, described her as a problem officer, who was unstable, insubordinate, and lacked discipline. In December 2013, Savchenko's 3rd Army Aviation Regiment was ordered to [[Kiev]] by President [[Viktor Yanukovych]].{{cite news |url=http://www.rferl.org/fullinfographics/infographics/the-many-faces-of-nadia-savchenko/27869488.html |title=The Many Faces Of Nadia Savchenko |publisher= [[Radio Free Europe]] |date= July 2016 }} Savchenko then (without permission from her commanding officer) joined the [[Euromaidan]] demonstrations. Savchenko kept a low profile during the protests; there is video of trying to persuade demonstrators not to throw petrol bombs at riot police. After [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|the president had fled Ukraine in late February 2014]], Savchenko and her unit returned to Brody. Angry over her unit not being deployed in the [[War in Donbass]] Savchenko defied orders and left Brody and she volunteered as an instructor in the [[Aidar Battalion]].{{r|TSN-Save}} ==Capture by Donbass People's Militia== During the [[War in Donbass]], Savchenko fought as a volunteer in the east of Ukraine in the [[Aidar Battalion]].{{r|BBC140709}}{{r|NBC140709}} On 17 June 2014, at 10:46 am{{cite web|url=http://112.international/politics/new-evidence-in-savchenkos-case-proves-her-innocence-lawyers-2447.html |title=New evidence in Savchenko's case proves her innocence, – lawyers |publisher=[[112 Ukraine]] |date=4 February 2016 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} she was captured near the village of [[Metalist (Slovianoserbsk Raion)|Metalist]], [[Slovianoserbsk Raion]], by members of the [[Zarya Battalion]], an armed pro-Russian militant group that declared allegiance to the self-declared [[People's Republic of Luhansk]].{{r|KP140701}} On 19 June, a video of her interrogation at an undisclosed location appeared on the internet; she was shown handcuffed to a metal pipe.{{r|BBC140709}}{{r|NBC140709}}{{r|VOU140620}} On 20 June, the chief of counter-intelligence Vladimir Gromov said that Savchenko was being well treated. On 22 June, there were media reports that Savchenko had been transferred to [[Donetsk]].{{r|TSN140622}} ==Detention and trial in the Russian Federation== [[File:Nadiya Savchenko, Moscow court, 10 February 2015 04.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Savchenko at the [[Moscow City Court|Moscow Basmanny court]] trial (February 10, 2015).]] {{see also|Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin}} On 8 July 2014, there were media reports that Nadiya Savchenko was being kept in a detention center in city of [[Voronezh]], the [[Russian Federation]]. On 9 July, {{Interlanguage link multi|Vladimir Markin (journalist)|ru|3=Маркин, Владимир Иванович|lt=Vladimir Markin}}, spokesman for [[Investigative Committee of Russia|Russia's Investigative Committee]] (a federal agency subordinate to the Russian President), confirmed that Savchenko was indeed held in Voronezh where she was facing charges of complicity in the 17 June killing of two Russian journalists, [[Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin|Igor Vladimirovich Kornelyuk]] (a correspondent for [[All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company]]), and sound producer [[Killing of Igor Kornelyuk and Anton Voloshin|Anton Voloshin]], who died during a mortar attack on a rebel checkpoint outside Luhansk.{{r|RFE140709}} Ukrainian officials said the reporters did not comply with safety requirements and were not accredited.{{r|BLG140710}} According to Savchenko's defence team, she was alibied by the billing data for Savchenko's and Kornelyuk's mobile phones, provided by [[Security Service of Ukraine|Ukrainian Security Service]], as she had already been captured by the Russian-backed separatists one hour before the mortar attack that killed Russian journalists.{{r|alibi}} Since late 2015, Russia's Investigative Committee insisted she crossed the border voluntarily without documents, and in the guise of a refugee.{{r|AP140709}} This contradicted previously published evidence and media reports: long before the alleged crossing, Russia's pro-Kremlin TV channel NTV reported that Savchenko had been captured by "rebels" and then handed over to the Russian authorities.{{r|WSJ140710}} Ukrainian officials said she had been illegally taken to Russia by Russian intelligence services in collaboration with pro-Russian rebels.{{r|MFA140709}}{{r|Liga140709}} In 2016, journalist Semen Zakruzhnyi followed the Investigative Committee's alleged route pointing out to numerous inconsistencies and concluding that neither Savchenko nor Russian investigators ever visited the places mentioned in the indictment.{{r|openrussia}} Ukraine's Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a strong protest against the illegal transfer of Savchenko to Russia, calling the kidnapping of the Ukrainian citizen an act of state terrorism.{{r|IR140708}} On 8 July, President [[Petro Poroshenko]] instructed the [[General Prosecutor of Ukraine]] to take all measures to bring about Savchenko's release.{{r|PUA140708}} In response, Vladimir Markin at Russia's Investigative Committee claimed that Savchenko was a terrorist and that the chances of her being released were on a par with those of Petro Poroshenko replacing [[Barack Obama]] as President of the United States.{{cite news|url=https://ru.tsn.ua/politika/v-rossii-po-hamski-obyasnili-kogda-osvobodyat-letchicu-nadezhdu-savchenko-376395.html|script-title=ru:В России по-хамски объяснили, когда освободят летчицу Надежду Савченко|trans-title=In Russia, they explained the release of the pilot Nadezhda Savchenko in a crude manner|language=ru|publisher=Tsn.ua|date=11 July 2014|accessdate=26 July 2017}} [[File:СВОБОДУ НАДІЇ САВЧЕНКО - FREEDOM TO NADIYA SAVCHENKO!.jpg|thumb|right|230px|A rally nearby Russian Consulate in [[Seattle]] in support of freedom for Savchenko, 2015]] During her long trial in Russia, Savchenko has been held in a cage—which is standard practice{{cite news |last1=Herszenhorn |first1=David M.|title=Presumed Innocent, but Caged in Court|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/19/world/europe/courtroom-cages-remain-common-despite-criticism.html|accessdate=20 April 2016|work=The New York Times|date=18 November 2013}} in Russia for defendants held without bail, despite the [[European Court of Human Rights]] ruling that defendants should never be held in a cage in the courtroom.{{r|NewYorker-20160410}} On 10 July, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko said in a website statement that her detention and trial is "A violation of all international agreements, all norms of law and is unacceptable."{{r|BLG140710}} President Poroshenko emphasized that "Nadiya Savchenko is a symbol of the struggle for Ukraine. While in captivity she has demonstrated the true, strong, martial Ukrainian spirit of a serviceman who doesn't betray the Motherland."{{r|PUA140710}} The President also said he had ordered a new lawyer for Savchenko.{{r|BLG140710}} [[File:2015-03-01 Шествие памяти Немцова L1510360 Free Savchenko.jpg|thumb|230px|[[Opposition to Vladimir Putin in Russia|Russian opposition]] rally in [[Moscow]], March 2015]] As of 11 July 2015, Savchenko's Russian defence lawyer is [[Mark Feygin]], who is known for his defence of [[Pussy Riot]].{{r|UP140711}} On 27 August 2014 during a hearing at the Sovetsky district court of Voronezh, Savchenko appeared wearing a T-shirt with the Ukrainian state symbol ([[Tryzub]]) and spoke exclusively in the [[Ukrainian language]].{{r|UP140827-voronezh}} She also stated that she had been detained in Russia since 24 June, not 30 June as the Russian investigation reported.{{r|UP140827-voronezh}} At the conclusion of the hearing, the court extended Savchenko's detention for a further two months and ordered that she be sent for a month to the [[Serbsky Institute]] for a forensic psychological evaluation, which Savchenko opposed.{{r|UP140827-psych}} On 22 December 2014, [[Moscow City Court]] upheld the decision to extend the arrest of Savchenko until the end of the investigation, which was scheduled to be concluded by 13 February 2015.{{r|NSsp221214}} Savchenko subsequently began a [[hunger strike]].{{cite news|last1=Oliphant|first1=Roland|title=Nadia Savchenko: The most controversial prisoner of the war in Ukraine |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11337627/Nadia-Savchenko-The-most-controversial-prisoner-of-the-war-in-Ukraine.html|accessdate=11 January 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=11 January 2015}} The [[European Union]] and the [[United States]] have condemned Savchenko's detention and have called for her release.{{r|IU141018}} Her lawyer, Mark Feygin, said she was a [[prisoner-of-war]].{{r|WP141224}} Savchenko officially became a Ukrainian delegate to the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]], or PACE, on 26 January 2015; thus on a legal level, she obtained [[parliamentary immunity]] in all PACE signatory states, including Russia, from that date. Despite this she was not released. [[Aleksey Pushkov]] of the Russian Duma stated that her appointment to PACE was an attack against Russia, and that gaining diplomatic immunity does not absolve one from previous crimes. However, the Russian delegation to PACE struck a different tone, stating that it "fully supports the release of Nadia Savchenko."{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.net/politics/1036372-rossiya-ne-sobiraetsya-osvobojdat-savchenko-i-reglament-pase-ey-ne-ukaz.html|publisher=Unian|title=Россия не собирается освобождать Савченко и регламент ПАСЕ ей не указ}}{{cite web|url=http://news.liga.net/news/politics/4884219-rossiyskaya_delegatsiya_v_pase_v_korne_pomenyala_pozitsiyu_po_savchenko.htm|publisher=Liga|title=Российская делегация в ПАСЕ в корне поменяла позицию по Савченко}}[http://www.rferl.mobi/a/ukraine-russia-savchenko-pilot-pace-immunity-hunger-strike/26814383.html PACE Grants Savchenko Immunity, Demands Her Release From Russian Jail], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (26 January 2015)
{{cite web|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/246245.html|publisher=[[Interfax Ukraine]]|title=Nadia Savchenko to obtain diplomatic immunity on January 26, Russia will have to let her go}} PACE has declined to strip Savchenko of her parliamentary immunity, and instead has stated that Savchenko must be immediately released, finding her 2014 abduction and subsequent imprisonment to be "a violation of international law amounting to her de facto kidnapping".{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/Xref-XML2HTML-en.asp?fileid=21538&lang=en |title=Resolution 2034 (2015) Final version: Challenge, on substantive grounds, of the still unratified credentials of the delegation of the Russian Federation |publisher=Council of Europe |date=2015 |accessdate=25 July 2017}} On 2 March 2015, President Petro Poroshenko awarded Savchenko with the title of [[Hero of Ukraine]].{{cite news |url=http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/3485964-poroshenko-prysvoyl-savchenko-zvanye-heroia-ukrayny |title=Порошенко присвоил Савченко звание Героя Украины |work=[[Korrespondent]] |date=2 March 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2016}} On 24 July 2015, a spokesman for the [[Investigative Committee of Russia]], contrary to the information of Savchenko's capture published earlier by [[Donetsk People's Republic]], stated that she voluntarily crossed the Russian border with intention of committing acts of sabotage and freely moved on the territory of [[Voronezh Oblast]] until 30 June when she was arrested.{{cite news|title=Russian migration service destroys Savchenko's abduction theory — Markin|url=http://tass.ru/en/russia/810454|agency=[[Russian News Agency TASS|TASS]]|date=24 July 2015}}{{cite web|title=Александр Бастрыкин: Яценюк воевал против российской армии в Чечне|url=http://www.rg.ru/2015/09/08/bastrikin-site.html|website=Российская газета|accessdate=2015-09-09}} In February 2016, the [[United States Department of State|US State department]]'s spokesperson [[Jen Psaki]] voiced deep concern over the continued ill-treatment and deteriorating health of Savchenko, and called on Russia to honour its commitments under the September 2014 [[Minsk agreement]]s, and the February 15 implementation plan by immediately releasing Savchenko and other Ukrainian hostages.{{r|Jen Psaki}} Other urges to release her followed.{{r|politolog.net}} On 7 March 2016, US Secretary of State [[John Kerry]] protested about Savchenko's continued detention, specifically mentioning concerns about her interrogations, solitary confinement, and forced "psychiatric evaluation".{{r|John Kerry}} [[File:РОЗЕНБЛАТ БОРИСЛАВ СОЛОМОНОВИЧ VADIM CHUPRINA ©.JPG|thumb|250px|Parliament of Ukraine in April 2015]] In March 2016, Savchenko wrote: "It is an absurd situation when those who abduct people and subject them to torture then act as if they have a right to judge them! How can one talk about a fair trial? In Russia, there are no trials or investigations—only a farce played out by Kremlin puppets. [...] those in the world with democratic values ought to learn their history lessons before it's too late and remember that there was a time when Europe was tolerant toward Hitler, and America wasn't decisive enough, and this led to World War II." On the 10 March 2016, while on a hunger strike, Nadiya Savchenko made a last statement to the court, which included the statement: "I admit no guilt and I recognize neither the court nor the verdict. If I am found guilty, I will not appeal. I want the entire democratic world to understand that Russia is a Third World country with a totalitarian regime and a petty tyrant for a dictator and it spits on international law and human rights."{{r|NewYorker-20160410}} According to her lawyer [[Mark Feygin]], "her case will certainly be decided in Kremlin by [[Putin]] and his associates".{{r|alibi}} On 21 March 2016, the court of [[Donetsk, Russia]] found Savchenko guilty of illegally crossing the Russian border and the murder of two Russian journalists.{{cite news|url=http://tass.ru/en/world/863897 |title=Ukrainian army ex-pilot found guilty of death of Russian journalists near Lugansk — court |publisher=Tass.ru |date=21 March 2016 |accessdate=25 July 2017}} Savchenko was freed in a prisoner swap on 25 May 2016{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36378173 |title=Russia 'frees Ukraine pilot Savchenko in prisoner swap' |date=2016-05-25 |access-date=2016-05-25 |publisher=BBC}} for two Russian servicemen.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/26/world/europe/ukraine-russia-prisoner-swap.html?_r=0 |title=Ukrainian Pilot, Nadiya Savchenko, Is Exchanged for 2 Russian Prisoners |date=2016-05-25 |access-date= 2016-12-27 |work=New York Times}}{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/europe/la-fg-ukraine-pilot-20160525-snap-story.html |title=Ukraine's first female combat pilot freed in prisoner exchange with Russia |date=2016-05-25 |access-date=2016-12-27 |work=Los Angeles Times}}{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/25/jailed-ukraine-pilot-nadia-savchenko-heads-home-after-prisoner-s/ |title=Jailed Ukraine pilot Nadia Savchenko heads home after prisoner swap with Russia |date=2016-05-25 |access-date=2016-12-27 |work=The Telegraph}} She was released from custody in [[Rostov-on-Don]] and immediately on a presidential flight brought to [[Boryspil]]. Technically, she was granted a pardon by president Vladimir Putin.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-savchenko-idUSKCN0YG0U8|title=Russia's Putin pardons Ukrainian pilot, sends her home in prisoner swap|last=Tsvetkova|first=Maria|date=25 May 2016 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=26 May 2016}} Immediately in the [[Boryspil International Airport]] she was awarded the Golden Star and received an honorary title of [[Hero of Ukraine]]. Since her release Savchenko suffers from [[insomnia]] and nightmares. ==Political career== [[File:Савченко Надія Вікторівна.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Savchenko in [[Verkhovna Rada|Parliament of Ukraine]], 31 May 2016]] In the October [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], Savchenko was placed first on the party list of [[Batkivshchyna]].{{r|KP141013}}{{r|NSmBCEC}} (In a June 2016 interview with ''[[Radio Free Europe]]'' she stated that the party wasn't her first choice, but it "isn't the worst".) In this same election her sister Vira Savchenko was also a candidate for Batkivshchyna in an [[electoral constituency]] in [[Yahotyn]].{{r|KP141008}}{{r|resultsOkurs1498}} Nadiya Savchenko was elected as a deputy to the [[Verkhovna Rada]], the parliament of Ukraine, as a result of the election.{{r|IU141119}} Because of this Savchenko resigned from the Ukrainian army on 7 November 2014.{{r|TASS-20141107}} The Russian government has recognized the elections of Ukraine, meaning that the Russian Federation was holding a member of parliament from another nation under arrest.{{r|112UA141029}}{{r|RV141028}}{{r|TASS-20141107}} Vira Savchenko finished third in her constituency with 7.02% of the votes (winner {{Interlanguage link multi|Serhiy Mishchenko|uk|3=Міщенко Сергій Григорович}} won 40.41%) and was thus not elected.{{r|resultsOkurs1498}} In late November 2014, Savchenko signed her parliamentary oath and passed it to Ukraine through her lawyer and was thus sworn in as [[People's Deputy of Ukraine]] (MP) on 27 November 2014.{{r|NSinRda714}}{{r|Rada-Bio}} On 25 December 2014, Savchenko was included in Ukraine's quota for representatives in the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE); as noted above, legally this granted her [[parliamentary immunity]] in all PACE signatory nations, including Russia.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/241787.html Verkhovna Rada includes pilot Savchenko in PACE delegation], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (25 December 2014) On 6 November 2015, Savchenko's first draft law was introduced to parliament, while she was imprisoned in Russia.[http://pda.pravda.com.ua/news/id_7087714/ Savchenko first co-author of the bill introduced by the Council], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (6 November 2015) On 27 May 2016, after returning from Russia in a prisoner exchange, Savchenko said she was prepared to become [[President of Ukraine]] if the Ukrainians wish so."[http://europe.newsweek.com/nadiya-savchenko-ready-run-president-ukraine-464200?rm=eu Nadiya Savchenko Ready to Run for President of Ukraine]". ''[[Newsweek]]''. 27 May 2016. In 2016, Savchenko left Batkivshchyna, but remained a member of its parliamentary faction.[http://www.unian.info/politics/1676361-savchenkos-sister-nadiia-left-batkivschyna-in-oct.html Savchenko's sister: Nadiia left Batkivschyna in Oct], [[UNIAN]] (13 December 2016)
[http://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-savchenko-rejects-criticism-for-meeting-separatists/28173875.html Savchenko Quits Ukrainian Party, But Plans To Continue Politics], [[Radio Free Europe]] (13 December 2016) This was announced on 12 December 2016 right after Savchenko had admitted she had recently held a secret meeting with separatist leaders [[Aleksandr Zakharchenko]] (of the [[Donetsk People's Republic]]) and [[Igor Plotnitsky]] (of the [[Luhansk People's Republic]]) in [[Minsk]].[http://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-savchenko-meets-separatists-minsk-plotnitsky-zakharchenko/28172257.html Savchenko Meets Russia-Backed Separatist Leaders, Stirring Outrage], [[Radio Free Europe]] (12 December 2016) On 15 December 2016, Batkivshchyna expelled Savchenko from its parliamentary faction in response to her Minsk meeting with Zakharchenko and Plotnitsky.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2016/12/20/7130387/ Savchenko was expelled from the faction "Fatherland"], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (20 December 2016) The party saw this meeting as "negotiations with terrorists" and "adamantly opposed" it.{{uk icon}} [http://pda.pravda.com.ua/news/id_7129988/ "Batkivshchyna" faction expelled from Savchenko], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (15 December 2016){{#tag:ref|On 16 December 2016 Batkivshchyna declared it would not use the [[Imperative mandate (Ukraine)|Imperative mandate]] (depriving her parliamentary seat) against Savchenko.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/391072.html Batkivschyna not to request Savchenko relinquish deputy mandate], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (16 December 2016) Faction leader [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] stated the party did not regret putting Savchenko in its electoral list for the [[2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election]], because "then we needed to rescue Ukraine's patriot from prison of the occupying country."|group=nb}} Following this controversy, the Ukrainian parliament stripped Savchenko of her PACE membership on 22 December 2016.{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/politics/ukraine-s-parliament-votes-to-dismiss-savchenko-from-pace-delegation-851958.html |title=Ukraine's parliament votes to dismiss Savchenko from PACE delegation |publisher=Uatoday.tv |date=22 December 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161223063357/http://uatoday.tv/politics/ukraine-s-parliament-votes-to-dismiss-savchenko-from-pace-delegation-851958.html |archivedate=23 December 2016}}[http://www.unian.info/politics/1692672-rada-dismisses-nadia-savchenko-from-pace-delegation.html Rada dismisses Nadia Savchenko from PACE delegation], [[UNIAN]] (22 December 2016) On 27 December 2016, Savchenko established the Civic Platform RUNA (an acronym for Ukrainian People's Revolution).{{cite news|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-savchenko-new-party-prisoner-swap/28200051.html|title=Ukraine's Savchenko Unveils New Public Movement|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe]]|date=27 December 2016|accessdate=26 July 2017}} According to Savchenko RUNA will not be a "political project" but rather a "mechanism" and a "natural association of people" who do not follow "populist slogans." In July 2017 her new political party "Social and Political Platform of Nadiya Savchenko" was officially registered.[https://www.unian.info/politics/2046281-weeks-milestones-calculated-escalation-overhaul-by-groysman-and-imitation-of-mobilization.html Week’s milestones. Calculated escalation, overhaul by Groysman, and imitation of mobilization], [[UNIAN]] (25 July 2017)
[https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/savchenko-informs-registration-party.html Savchenko informs about registration of her party], [[Kyiv Post]] (19 July 2017) The same month she stated her intent to take part in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2019|2019 Ukrainian presidential election]].[https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/savchenko-intends-run-president-ukraine.html Savchenko intends to run for president of Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (27 July 2017) == The charge of preparing a terrorist attack in Ukraine == On 15 March 2018, the Attorney General of Ukraine [[Yuriy Lutsenko]] charged Savchenko with preparing a terrorist attack on the Ukrainian parliament.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hh6YpsCoZGw|title=У ГПУ є незаперечні докази, що Савченко планувала теракт в Раді – Луценко|first=|last=Радіо Свобода Україна|date=15 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018|via=YouTube}} According to Lutsenko, she planned dropping the building of the [[Verkhovna Rada]] using [[Mortar (weapon)#Modern mortar|mortar fire]] and finish off all survived members of the Rada with automatic weapons.{{cite web|url=https://112.ua/politika/lucenko-u-sledstviya-est-dokazatelstva-chto-savchenko-lichno-planirovala-terakt-v-zale-verhovnoy-rady-437364.html|title=Луценко: Савченко лично планировала теракт в зале Верховной Рады|website=112.ua|accessdate=22 March 2018}} On 15 March 2018 Lutsenko asked parliament to annul Savchenko's parliamentary immunity in order to prosecute and arrest her. On 22 March 2018, parliament stripped Savchenko of her [[parliamentary immunity]] and allowed her arrest.{{cite news|title=Rada strips MP Savchenko of parliamentary immunity, allows arrest|url=https://www.unian.info/m/politics/10052528-rada-strips-mp-savchenko-of-parliamentary-immunity-allows-arrest.html|accessdate=22 March 2018|language=en}} The same day she was arrested on suspicion of planning an assault on parliament and supporting a [[coup]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43504396|title=Ukraine arrests war hero over 'coup plot'|date=22 March 2018|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018|via=www.bbc.com}} Savchenko claimed that she did not plan any terrorist attack, but talked with undercover Ukrainian government [[agent provocateur]]s who sought to discredit her.{{cite news|title=Opposition Ukrainian MP and war hero detained on coup plot charges|url=http://www.euronews.com/2018/03/22/opposition-ukrainian-mp-and-war-hero-detained-on-coup-plot-charges|accessdate=22 March 2018|language=en}} ==Political views== Savchenko believes that Ukraine should become "more or less a dictatorship" with a strong leader to stand up to Russia and win,[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/nadiya-savchenko/article34144815/ Freed from Putin’s Russia, a Ukrainian pilot puts Poroshenko and his party – ‘enemy No. 2’ – in her sights], [[The Globe and Mail]] (Feb. 28, 2017) with [[Augusto Pinochet]], [[Margaret Thatcher]], [[Angela Merkel]], [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[Nelson Mandela]] as examples. Savchenko has suggested Ukraine should accept the [[2014 Russian annexation of Crimea]] as an attempt to end the [[War in Donbass]]. On 15 March 2018 Savchenko claimed that "people now lawmakers" were involved with the [[List of people killed during Euromaidan|deadly sniper shootings]] during the [[2014 Ukrainian Revolution]] and that the government that came to power after the 2014 Ukrainian Revolution did not want to thoroughly investigate these shootings.{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-savchenko-terror-plot-accusations/29101770.html|title='War Hero' Savchenko Accused Of Terror Plot|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=22 March 2018}} ==Public image== [[File:U.S. Independence Day Reception, Kyiv, Ukraine, July 1, 2016 (28181767191).jpg|thumb|Savchenko at the residence of [[Geoffrey R. Pyatt]], the U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine, 1 July 2016]] Savchenko's trial has caused a significant response inside Russia and internationally.{{r|DW-20160208}}{{r|EEAS-2016}}{{r|freesavchenko}}{{r|euobserver-20160314}}{{cite web|url=https://osce.usmission.gov/nadiya-savchenko-ukrainians-held-russia-statement-pc-2/|title=On Nadiya Savchenko and other Ukrainians held by Russia: Statement to the PC|publisher=osce.usmission.gov|date=28 April 2016|accessdate=25 July 2017}} After news of her arrest was reported on 19 June, Savchenko became the subject of an impassioned Ukrainian [[social media]] campaign portraying her as a [[Folk hero|national hero]].{{r|BBC140711}} This social media campaign used the [[hashtag]] #SaveOurGirl (that mid-July 2014 had generated more than 15,000 [[Tweet (Twitter)|tweets]]); apparently inspired by the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls used in the May 2014 [[Chibok schoolgirl kidnapping]] social media worldwide campaign.{{r|BBC140711}} According to [[BBC News]] Savchenko is portrayed extremely negatively in the [[media of Russia]]: "Crude, and at times sexist, innuendo is used to demonise Ms Savchenko".{{r|BBC140711}} The Russian daily ''[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]'' said that Savchenko is known as a "killing machine in a skirt", and Tvoy Den called her "Satan's daughter".{{r|BBC140711}} Russian social media, however, tends to be more nuanced towards her with several anti-Kremlin users mocking perceived oddities in the Russian authorities' version of events, in particular their claim that she entered the country as a refugee.{{r|BBC140711}} In March 2016, Russian composer [[Vladimir Nazarov (musician)|Vladimir Nazarov]] wrote in an open letter to Putin saying that "not even in my worst nightmare could I have imagined that I would have to ask you not to kill a woman."{{cite web|url=https://tvrain.ru/articles/nazarov-405042/|script-title=ru:'В страшном кошмаре не мог представить, что буду просить вас не убивать женщину'|trans-title='In the most terrible nightmare I could not imagine that I would ask you not to kill a woman'|language=ru|website=tvrain.ru|date=8 March 2016|accessdate=26 July 2017}} In March 2016, Russian opposition politician [[Alexei Navalny]] stated about Savchenko's trial, "However you look at it, this doesn't benefit Russia". Navalny said that whoever planned to make Savchenko "a trophy prisoner" had miscalculated. He described the trial as such an "obvious stitch-up" you could "see the threads".{{cite news|last=Rainsford|first=Sarah|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35886684|title=Savchenko case: Will Kremlin release Ukraine pilot?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=24 March 2016|accessdate=26 July 2017}} When Savchencko was released from Russian prison in May 2016 [[Opinion polling for the Ukrainian presidential election, 2019|opinion polls for the Ukrainian presidential election]] showed 15% would vote for her; by early 2017 this number was below 5%. Savchenko blames an alleged government smear campaign (that is casting her as someone who may have been turned into a Russian agent) for this collapse. == See also == Other Ukrainians detained by Russia include: * [[Oleg Sentsov]] * [[Olexandr Kolchenko]] * Stanislav Klykh{{cite web|last=Coynash|first=Halya|url=http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1458342762|title=Russia uses Kadyrov's thugs against defence witnesses in Ukrainian political trial|website=khpg.org|date=25 March 2016|accessdate=26 July 2017}} * Mykola Karpyuk * Akhtem Chiygoz ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} == References == из украинского героя в российский символ|trans-title=Commentary: Nadezhda Savchenko - from Ukrainian hero to Russian symbol|language=ru|agency=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=8 March 2016|accessdate=25 July 2017}} {{cite news|url=http://collections.internetmemory.org/haeu/content/20160313172652/http://eeas.europa.eu/top_stories/2016/100316_free-savchenko_en.htm|title=Mogherini calls for immediate release of Nadiya Savchenko|work=[[European External Action Service]]|date=10 March 2016|accessdate=25 July 2017}} {{cite web | url=http://freesavchenko.tilda.ws/ | title=Free Savchenko: Open letter to European leaders | publisher=Tilda | accessdate=15 March 2016 | website=freesavchenko. tilda.ws}} {{cite news | url=https://euobserver.com/foreign/132665 | title=EU ministers to speak out on Ukrainian pilot | work=EUuobserver | date=14 March 2016 | accessdate=15 March 2016 | author=Rettman, Andrew | location=Brussels}} {{cite news|last1=Dzhanpoladova|first1=Natalia|last2=Gostev|first2=Aleksandr|script-title=ru:Алиби Надежды Савченко|trans-title=Nadezhda Savchenko's alibi|language=ru|url=https://www.svoboda.org/a/26748995.html|agency=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|Radio Liberty]]|date=17 December 2014|accessdate=25 July 2017}} }} == External links == {{sisterlinks|d=Q17318904|q=no|n=no|b=no|v=no|voy=no|m=no|mw=no|s=no|species=no|c=Category:Nadiya Savchenko|wikt=no}} * [http://savesavchenko.tsn.ua Savchenko case] at [[1+1 (TV channel)|1+1]] {{uk icon}} * [http://www.eurochicago.com/2015/03/ukrainian-g-i-jane/ Why Russia needs the Ukrainian 'G.I. Jane' Savchenko imprisoned] * {{Facebook|Nadia-Savchenko-423442834478228}} {{2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Savchenko, Nadiya}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kiev]] [[Category:Women in the Ukrainian military]] [[Category:Ukrainian Air Force officers]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Russia]] [[Category:Ukrainian people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:Ukrainian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Ukrainian prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:2014 controversies]] [[Category:People of the Euromaidan]] [[Category:People with insomnia]] [[Category:Pro-Ukrainian people of the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian victims of human rights abuses]] [[Category:Ukrainian people taken hostage]] [[Category:Women in the Iraq War]] [[Category:Women in 21st-century warfare]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order For Courage, 3rd class]] [[Category:Batkivshchyna politicians]] [[Category:Independent politicians in Ukraine]] [[Category:Individuals designated as terrorist by the government of Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian women in politics]] [[Category:Eighth convocation members of the Verkhovna Rada]] [[Category:Ukrainian military personnel of the War in Donbass]] [[Category:Recipients of the title of Hero of Ukraine]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Gold Star (Ukraine)]] [[Category:Ukrainian female aviators]] [[Category:21st-century women politicians]] [[Category:Hunger strikes]]

revision.text:
'''Olumbe Bassir''' (1919–2001) was a [[Sierra Leone]]an [[scientist]], author and academic.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=AVgAFk6u_CMC&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=olumbe+bassir#v=onepage&q=olumbe%20bassir&f=false|title=New Scientist:The Professor's Dilema|volume=56|page=17|number=514|publisher=Reed Business Information|date=October 5, 1972|accessdate=November 26, 2014}}</ref> His primary contributions to research were in the areas of aflatoxins, nutrition, and peace research.
==Early life and education== Born in [[Senegal]] to Sierra Leonean [[Oku people (Sierra Leone)|Aku]] parents in 1919, Abdul Rahman Bassir was raised in [[Fourah Bay]] area, in the municipality of [[Freetown]], by his parents Abdul and Isatu Bassir. He attended the Prince of Wales Secondary School where he passed the Senior Cambridge examination with exemption from London matriculation. In 1946, after a short teaching spell at the prestigious Bo Government Secondary School, he attended to [[Yaba College]] where he obtained the Higher National Diploma. He then went to the United Kingdom, where he earned the Bachelor of Science degree in 1949 and PhD in 1951 from [[Liverpool University]].
==Career== He spent most of his professional career at the [[University of Ibadan]], where he founded the [[Biochemistry]] and [[Microbiology]] departments. He laid the foundation of what became the first medical school in West Africa. By 1958, he was already a full professor. His academic specialty was [[nutrition]] and biochemical [[toxicology]]. He was at various times Head of those two departments, Dean of faculty and also served as acting Vice Chancellor.
He had written at least 250 professional papers by 1972 when [[University of London]] conferred the coveted doctor of science degree (D.Sc.) on him. He had performed very successful lecture tours in the then [[Soviet Union]], the United Kingdom, and the United States of America among others.
Olumbe Bassir was the author of several books. His 1957 book [[Anthology of West African Verse]]<ref>{{Cite book|url= https://books.google.com/?id=SS47AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=olumbe+bassir#v=onepage&q=olumbe%20bassir&f=false|title= Mother is Gold: A Study in West African Literature|author=Andrian A Roscoe|page=14|isbn= 9780521096447|year= 1971}}</ref> was seminal in introducing written African poetry to Western audiences. His other popular books include [[Handbook of Practical Biochemistry]] (1963) and [[Metabolism of Afflatoxins and other Mycotoxins]] (1989).
In 1968, he formed a partnership with Tecwyn Williams through the British Inter-University Council for Higher Education Overseas. The programme's research division helped developed the Drug Metabolism and Biochemical Toxicology research program at Ibadan and contributed in fostering interest and making interesting findings in animal nutritional habits.
After retiring from the University of Ibadan, he remained active for several years, continuing to act as editor of the [[West African Journal of Biology and Applied Chemistry]]. He also served as chairman of the Welcome Nigeria Fund, which became the Bassir-Thomas Biomedical Foundation in the early 1990s. He also regularly organised the annual Open House Colloquim.
==Advocacy and Activism== Olumbe Bassir was a lifelong advocate for peace, and was an active member of the [[Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs]]. He also contributed to the Universities and the Quest for Peace. He was also sympathetic to the [[Fabian Society]] which he flirted with in his student days in England. He founded the Association of University Teachers in Nigeria which later became the Academic Staff Union of Universities. Despite being non-partisan, he helped develop the manifesto of the [[Action Group (Nigeria)|Action Group]].
==Personal life== His name "Olumbe" means "God exists" in [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://destee.com/index.php?threads/yoruba-names-and-their-meanings.57736/|website=Destee|title=Black Spirituality Religion : Yoruba names and their meanings|accessdate=December 5, 2014}}</ref> He married Constance while still resident in the UK. He had 12 children. In 2000, he suffered a blood clot in the brain due to a traumatic injury to the head. Despite successful surgery and recuperation he died at [[Ibadan]] on May 23, 2001.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bassir, Olumbe}} [[Category:Nigerian people of Liberated African descent]] [[Category:Aku people]] [[Category:Sierra Leone Liberated Africans]] [[Category:Nigerian academics]] [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:Nigerian scientists]] [[Category:Yoruba scientists]] [[Category:University of Ibadan faculty]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Liverpool]] [[Category:Senegalese people of Yoruba descent]] [[Category:20th-century Nigerian people]] [[Category:Yoruba academics]] [[Category:Yaba Higher College alumni]] [[Category:Senegalese expatriates in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Nigerian expatriates in the United Kingdom]]

'''Ramkrishna Biswas''' (? - 4 August 1931) was a [[Bengalis|Bengali]] revolutionary and martyr. He was an active member of [[Surya Sen]]'s revolutionary group.
==Early life== Biswas was born in Saroatali, [[Chittagong]] in [[British India]]. His father's name was Durga Kripa Biswas. In 1928, Biswas came first in entrance examination among the district. He joined the revolutionary movement led by ''Masterda'' Surya Sen. In 1930 he was seriously wounded while preparing bombs.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Sansab Bangali Charitavidhan (Bengali)|last=Vol - I|first=Subodh C. Sengupta & Anjali Basu|publisher=Sahitya Sansad|year=2002|isbn=81-85626-65-0|location=Kolkata|pages=480}}</ref>
==Revolutionary activities== Surya Sen and his followers decided to assassinate Mr. Craig, Inspector General of Police, Chittagong. Biswas and Kalipada Chakrabarty were assigned for this task, subsequently on 1 December 1930 they went to Chandpur station but mistakenly killed a rail officer Traini Mukherjee instead of Craig. Biswas and Kalipada Chakravarty were arrested on 2 December 1931.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=Y6Dw3W9ubLkC&pg=RA2-PT151&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Netaji Subhas Bose: Bengal Revolution and Independence|last=Reva Chatterjee|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 17, 2018}}</ref> Biswas's family and friends lacked enough money required to travel to Chittagong to Alipore Jail of Kolkata. At that time [[Pritilata Waddedar]] was staying in [[Kolkata]] and was asked to go to Alipore Jail and meet Biswas. She introduced herself as his sister and met him. His martyrdom later inspired Pritilata.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=7jaaDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT222&lpg=PT222&dq=ramkrishna+biswas+Surya+Sen&source=bl&ots=Bs2AjbpOeP&sig=u7aMN-tKwx4ngsN01gqgfHjRmpY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjL06H22_PZAhXIrI8KHTGCAC84ChDoAQg6MAQ#v=onepage&q=ramkrishna%20biswas%20Surya%20Sen&f=false|title=Indias Struggle Quarter of Century 1921 to 1946|last=Part I|first=Arun Chandra Guha|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/op-ed/politics/pritilata-waddedar-politics-remembrance-147139|title=Pritilata Waddedar: Politics of remembrance|last=Upashana Salam|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 17, 2018}}</ref>
==Death== Biswas was sentenced to death after his trial. In the morning of 4 August 1931 he was executed in [[Alipore Jail|Alipore Central Jail]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19310814-1.2.9|title=RAMKRISHNA BISWAS.|last=|first=|date=|website=eresources.nlb.gov.sg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=March 17, 2018}}</ref> Kalipada Chakrabarty was transported to [[Cellular Jail]].<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Steve Southerland | image = Steve Southerland, Official Portrait, 112th Congress.jpg | imagesize = | state = [[Florida]] | district = [[Florida's 2nd congressional district|2nd]] | term_start = January 3, 2011 | term_end = January 3, 2015 | preceded = [[Allen Boyd]] | succeeded = [[Gwen Graham]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | birth_name = William Steve Southerland, II | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|10|10}} | birth_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], [[United States|USA]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | alma_mater = [[Jefferson State Community College]] [[Associate of Arts|A.A.]]
[[Troy State University]] [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] | profession = [[Lobbyist]], [[Mortician]] | spouse = Susan Southerland | children = four | residence = [[Panama City, Florida]], U.S. | religion = [[Southern Baptist]] | website = [http://www.southerlandforcongress.com/ Southerland For Congress] }} '''William Steve Southerland, II'''[http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/g/r/a/Leslie-Grant/BOOK-0001/0011-0004.html Genealogy site for Southerland family] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070129040559/http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/g/r/a/Leslie-Grant/BOOK-0001/0011-0004.html |date=January 29, 2007 }} (born October 10, 1965) is a lobbyist https://www.capitolhillcg.com/team/steve-southerland/ and former American politician and member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] who served as the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|FL|2}} from 2011 to 2015. The district includes most of the eastern [[Florida Panhandle]], from [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]] to the state capital, [[Tallahassee]]. He was narrowly defeated for re-election in 2014, one of only two incumbent House Republicans to lose their seat in the general election that year, the other being [[Lee Terry]] of [[Nebraska]].https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/11/05/read-in-clean-sweep-edition/ ==Early life and education== Southerland was born on October 10, 1965 in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].{{cite news | title = Guide to the New Congress | date = November 4, 2010 | url = http://innovation.cq.com/newmember/2010elexnguide.pdf | work = [[Roll Call|CQ Roll Call]] | accessdate = November 24, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110708200600/http://innovation.cq.com/newmember/2010elexnguide.pdf | archivedate = July 8, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}https://news.yahoo.com/s/cq/20101103/pl_cq_politics/politics000003758170_2 He is a lifelong resident of [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]]. He is the fourth generation of five in his family to live in [[Bay County, Florida|Bay County]]. In 1983, he graduated from [[A. Crawford Mosley High School]]. He earned a [[B.S.]] degree in [[Business Management]] from [[Troy State University]] and an [[Associate of Arts|A.A.]] degree in [[Mortuary Science]] from [[Jefferson State Community College|Jefferson State Junior College]].[http://www.meaningfulfunerals.net/fh/aboutus/staff_member.cfm?stf_id=3686&fh_id=10883&s_id=76B1D6D2086F40C3F0FB186F2454E6CC www.meaningfulfunerals.net] ==Business career== Southerland is co-owner/president of Southerland Family Funeral Homes, founded in 1955.{{cite web|title=Product Showroom|url=http://www.meaningfulfunerals.net/fh/aboutus/staff_member.cfm?stf_id=3686&fh_id=10883&s_id=76B1D6D2086F40C3F0FB186F2454E6CC|website=Southerland Family Funeral Homes and Crematory|accessdate=September 8, 2014}} He is also a founding partner in two other businesses: Genesis Granite & Stone, LLC and K & B Land and Timber Company, LLC. Florida's governor{{who|date=January 2015}}{{when|date=January 2015}} appointed him as chairman of the Early Learning Coalition of Northwest Florida{{cite web|title=Education|url=http://southerland.house.gov/index.cfm/education|website=House of Representatives|accessdate=September 8, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908225056/http://southerland.house.gov/index.cfm/education|archivedate=September 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}} and to the Florida Board of Funeral Directors,{{cite web|title=Rep. Steve Southerland II (R-Fla.)|url=http://www.rollcall.com/members/32344.html|website=Roll Call|accessdate=September 8, 2014}} where he served as chairman in his second term. ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Elections=== ====2010==== {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Florida, 2010#District 2*}} Southerland won the Republican primary against Eddie Hendry, Ron McNeil, Barbara F. Olschner and David Scholl.{{cite web|last=Blake|first=Aaron|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/65637-second-goper-signs-up-to-face-rep-boyd|title=Second GOPer signs up to face Rep. Boyd - The Hill's Blog Briefing Room|publisher=Thehill.com|date=October 30, 2009|accessdate=August 21, 2010}} He was part of the [[National Republican Congressional Committee#GOP Young Gun Program|GOP Young Gun Program]].[http://blogs.cqpolitics.com/eyeon2010/2010/08/nrcc-adds-six-candidates-to-yo.html CQ politics blogsite] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831180158/http://blogs.cqpolitics.com/eyeon2010/2010/08/nrcc-adds-six-candidates-to-yo.html |date=August 31, 2010 }}{{cite news|title=NRCC Expands Lower Tiers in 'Young Guns'|url=http://www.rollcall.com/news/nrcc_expands_lower_tiers_in_yo-65057-1.html|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=Roll Call|date=July 21, 2010}} He was endorsed by U.S. Congressmen [[Eric Cantor]], [[Jeff Miller (Florida politician)|Jeff Miller]], former State House Speaker [[Allan Bense]], former Democratic Governor [[Wayne Mixson]], State Rep. [[Jimmy Patronis]], State Rep. [[Marti Coley]], former U.S. Congressman [[James W. Grant|Bill Grant]], former [[Alaska]] Governor [[Sarah Palin]], [[Lynn Haven, Florida|Lynn Haven]] Mayor, [[Walter Kelley]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20101028215855/http://www.southerlandforcongress.com/Default.aspx?tabid=4091 Southerland For Congress.com] It was Southerland's first bid for elected office. Southerland faced seven-term Democratic incumbent [[Allen Boyd]] in the November general election. Independent candidates Paul C. McKain and Dianne Berryhill were also on the ballot, and Ray Netherwood had qualified as a write-in candidate. [[Real Clear Politics]] rated this race a "Leans GOP".{{cite news|title=Florida 2nd District - Southerland vs. Boyd|date=October 28, 2010|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2010/house/fl/florida_2nd_district_southerland_vs_boyd-1372.html|work=[[Real Clear Politics]]|accessdate=October 29, 2010}} [[CQ Politics]] rated the election as a toss up.[http://www.cqpolitics.com/wmspage.cfm?parm1=5 CQPolitics] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224144340/http://www.cqpolitics.com/wmspage.cfm?parm1=5 |date=February 24, 2009 }} In the November 2 general election, Southerland defeated Boyd with 52 percent of the vote. Southerland is the first freshman Republican to represent the 2nd since its formation in 1963 (it was the 9th District from 1963–1967 and has been the 2nd since 1967).{{cite news|last1=Bojorquez|first1=Manuel|title=Fla. congressman hears it from constituents about Syria|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/fla-congressman-hears-it-from-constituents-about-syria/|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=CBS News|date=September 4, 2013}} The only other Republican to ever represent this district, [[James W. Grant|Bill Grant]], was originally elected as a Democrat in 1986, but switched parties midway through his second term. ====2012==== {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Florida, 2012#District 2}} Southerland defeated former State Senator [[Alfred Lawson, Jr.]] 53% 175,856 votes to 47% 157,634 out of 333,718 ballots cast on November 6, 2012 for his re-election to a second term in Congress. ====2014==== {{Main|United States House of Representatives elections in Florida, 2014#District 2}} Southerland ran for re-election. He ran unopposed for the Republican nomination in the primary,{{cite news|title=2014 Florida House Primaries Results|url=http://www.politico.com/2014-election/results/map/house/florida/#.VAAprUu0ZuY|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=Politico|date=August 28, 2014}} and faced [[Gwen Graham]] in the general election on November 4, 2014. Southerland lost the election, receiving 49.56% of the vote to Graham's 50.44%.{{cite web|title=Florida Department of State - Division of Elections|url=http://enight.elections.myflorida.com/FederalOffices/|accessdate=11/5/2014}} ===Tenure=== Southerland opposes military intervention in Syria.{{cite news|last1=McLaughlin|first1=Tom|title=Miller, Southerland Voice Their Opinions on Syria|url=http://www.nwfdailynews.com/local/miller-southerland-voice-their-opinions-on-syria-1.196990|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=NWFDaily News|date=September 3, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908224358/http://www.nwfdailynews.com/local/miller-southerland-voice-their-opinions-on-syria-1.196990|archivedate=September 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}} He voted for the [[Amash–Conyers Amendment]], which would prohibit the collection of records by the National Security Agency under the Patriot Act.{{cite news|title=Amash amendment: the full roll call|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jul/25/amash-amendment-full-roll-call|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=July 24, 2013}} He voted against the [[Agricultural Act of 2014|2014 Farm Bill]], a $1 trillion bill which expanded crop insurance for farmers by $7 billion over the next decade and created new subsidies for rice and peanut growers that would kick in when prices drop.{{cite news|last1=Rogers|first1=Alex|title=How Food Stamps Killed the Farm Bill|url=http://swampland.time.com/2013/06/21/food-stamps-killed-the-farm-bill/|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=Time|date=June 21, 2013}} Southerland has stated that he wants to replace the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] "with an approach that incorporates free-market principles. The article cited states: "Southerland prefers a system that would give consumers greater access to health savings accounts and force greater competition on insurance providers while retaining the Obamacare provision that prohibits insurers from denying coverage for pre-existing conditions. He voiced support for tort reform to help prevent frivolous lawsuits against doctors." "{{cite news|last1=Olwell|first1=Chris|title=Medical group endorses Southerland|url=http://www.newsherald.com/news/government/medical-group-endorses-southerland-1.361822?page=1|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=News Herald|date=August 20, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140908225930/http://www.newsherald.com/news/government/medical-group-endorses-southerland-1.361822?page=1|archivedate=September 8, 2014|df=mdy-all}} On July 11, 2014, Southerland introduced the [[Waters of the United States Regulatory Overreach Protection Act of 2014 (H.R. 5078; 113th Congress)]], a bill that would prohibit the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) and the [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] (Corps) from implementing or enforcing certain proposed regulations regarding the use of the nation's waters and [[wetland]]s.{{cite web|title=CBO - H.R. 5078|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45619|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}{{cite web|title=H.R. 5078 - Summary|url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/5078|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=September 10, 2014}} ===Committee assignments=== *'''[[United States House Committee on Natural Resources|Committee on Natural Resources]]''' **[[United States House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Fisheries, Wildlife, Oceans and Insular Affairs|Subcommittee on Fisheries, Wildlife, Oceans and Insular Affairs]] *'''[[United States House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure|Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure]]''' **[[United States House Transportation Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation|Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation]] **[[United States House Transportation Subcommittee on Highways and Transit|Subcommittee on Highways and Transit]] ===Caucus memberships=== * [[Congressional Constitution Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=https://congressionalconstitutioncaucus-garrett.house.gov/about-us/membership|format=|publisher=Congressional Constitution Caucus|date=|accessdate=8 May 2018}} ==Personal life== Steve and Susan Southerland have four children. He is a member of Northstar Church, a nondenominational church in [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]].{{cite news|last=Staff|first=|title=Ten Southern Baptists sworn in as new reps.|url=http://www.bpnews.net/bpnews.asp?id=34378|accessdate=25 December 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226010629/http://www.bpnews.net/34378|archivedate=December 26, 2014 |newspaper=Baptist Press|date=5 January 2011}} Southerland served as Chairman of the Bay County Chamber of Commerce and Chairman of [[the Salvation Army]] Advisory Board as well as such community boards including the [[Florida State University Panama City]] Development Board and the Covenant Hospice Foundation Board.[http://southerlandforcongress.com/Default.aspx?tabid=4011 Southerland For Congress] He is a member of the [[National Rifle Association]] and founding member and former Vice President of the Bay Patriots. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * {{dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Florida/Government/Federal/US_House/Steve_Southerland_%5BR-02%5D/|Steve Southerland}} * {{CongLinks | congbio=S001186 | votesmart=124329 | fec=H0FL02110 | congress=steve-southerland/2000 }} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Florida | district=2 | before=[[Allen Boyd]] | after=[[Gwen Graham]] |years=January 3, 2011 – January 3, 2015}} {{end}} {{U.S. Florida Representatives}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Southerland, Steve}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Florida Republicans]] [[Category:People from Panama City, Florida]] [[Category:Troy University alumni]] [[Category:American Christians]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Florida]] [[Category:Funeral directors]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]]

{{about|the archaeologist|the British wine writer|Stuart Pigott}} {{more footnotes|date=February 2008}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Stuart Piggott |honorific_suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|CBE|FBA|FSA|FSA Scot|size=100%}} [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland|FSA Scot]] |image = Stuartpiggott.jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 28 May 1910 |birth_place = [[Petersfield, Hampshire]] |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1996|9|23|1910|5|28}} |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = British |nationality = British |field = [[Archaeology]] |spouse = |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |influences = [[Mortimer Wheeler]] |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Stuart Ernest Piggott''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|CBE|FBA|FSA|size=100%|sep=,}}, [[FRSE]] [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland|FSA Scot]] (28 May 1910 – 23 September 1996) was a British [[archaeologist]], best known for his work on prehistoric [[Wessex]].
==Early life== Piggott was born in [[Petersfield, Hampshire]], the son of G. H. O. Piggott, and was educated there at [[Churcher's College]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
==Career== On leaving school in 1927 Piggott took up a post as assistant at [[Reading Museum]], where he developed an expertise in [[Neolithic]] pottery.
In 1928 he joined the [[Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales]] and spent the next five years producing a revolutionary study of the site of [[Butser Hill]], near [[Petersfield, Hampshire|Petersfield]]. He also worked with Eliot and Cecil Curwen on their excavations at [[The Trundle]] [[causewayed enclosure]] in [[Sussex]].
In the 1930s he began working for [[Alexander Keiller (archaeologist)|Alexander Keiller]], an amateur archaeologist who funded his work from the profits of his [[Dundee Marmalade]] business. The two dug numerous sites in Wessex including [[Avebury]] and [[Kennet Avenue]]. In 1933, he joined his friend [[Grahame Clark]] in writing the highly significant paper, "The age of the British flint mines" (''[[Antiquity (journal)|Antiquity]]'', 1933): the resultant controversy led to the foundation of the [[Prehistoric Society]]. Still without any formal archaeological qualification, Piggott enrolled at [[Mortimer Wheeler]]'s [[UCL Institute of Archaeology|Institute of Archaeology]], London, taking his diploma in 1936. It was also here that he met his wife, Peggy ([[Margaret Guido]]). In 1937 he published another seminal paper, "The early Bronze Age in Wessex", and with his wife went on in June 1939 to join the burial chamber excavations at [[Sutton Hoo]] at the invitation of [[Charles Phillips (archaeologist)|Charles Phillips]].
During the [[Second World War]] Piggott worked as an air photo interpreter. He was posted to [[India]], where he spent time studying the archaeology of the sub-continent, eventually leading him to write the books ''Some Ancient Cities of India'' (1946) and ''Prehistoric India'' (1950). These experiences provided him with a valuable external view of European prehistory, which was to prove useful on his return to Britain.
After the war he went to [[Oxford University|Oxford]] to study the work of [[William Stukeley]], but in 1946 was offered the [[Lord John Abercromby|Abercromby]] [[List of professorships at the University of Edinburgh|Chair in Archaeology]] at [[Edinburgh University]] (now part of the [[University of Edinburgh School of History, Classics and Archaeology|School of History, Classics and Archaeology]]), in succession to [[V. Gordon Childe|Gordon Childe]]. Piggott succeeded in making Edinburgh an archaeology department of international standing. He continued to publish widely. His book ''Neolithic Cultures of the British Isles'' (1954) was highly influential, until [[radiocarbon dating]] tests exposed flaws in its chronology. Piggott considered that radiocarbon dating was "archaeologically unacceptable", because every other shred of evidence pointed towards his dates being correct. ''Ancient Europe'' (1965) remained a popular survey of Old World prehistory for more than twenty years, demonstrating his view of the solidarity and continuity of the past in Europe. In 1956 his childless marriage ended.
In 1958 Piggott published a survey of Scottish prehistory, ''Scotland before History'', and in 1959 a popular introductory volume, ''Approach to Archaeology''. He was president of the Prehistoric Society from 1960 to 1963, president of the [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland]] from 1963 to 1967, president of the [[Council for British Archaeology]] from 1967 to 1970, and a trustee of the [[British Museum]] between 1968 and 1974). In 1963, he produced a thorough analysis of the [[Beaker culture]] in Britain, published as part of a [[Festschrift]] dedicated to [[Cyril Fox]]. Piggott's interest in the early history of the practice of archaeology led to him writing ''The Druids'' in 1968 whilst other books included ''Prehistoric Societies'' (with [[Grahame Clark]]), ''The Earliest Wheeled Transport'' (1983), followed by its sequel, ''Wagon, Chariot and Carriage'' (1992). His final book was ''Ancient Britain and the Antiquarian Imagination'' (1989).
He died of a heart attack at his home near [[Wantage]] in [[Berkshire]] on 23 September 1996. His remains were cremated on 30 September at [[Oxford]] crematorium.
==Family==
In 1936 he married Cecily Margaret Preston. They were divorced in 1954.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
==Excavations== Sites he excavated (often with [[Richard J. C. Atkinson|Richard Atkinson]]) included:
*[[Cairnpapple Hill]] in [[West Lothian]] *[[Wayland's Smithy]] in [[Oxfordshire]] *[[West Kennet Long Barrow]] and [[Stonehenge]] in [[Wiltshire]]
==Honours== In 1957 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Robert Schlapp]], [[David Whitteridge]], [[Sidney Newman]], and [[James Ritchie (naturalist)|James Ritchie]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
He received the [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] in 1972, and was awarded numerous academic awards from scholarly institutions in Britain and abroad. He retired from the Abercromby Chair in 1977 and was awarded the gold medal of the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]] in 1983 and the [[Grahame Clark Medal]] of the [[British Academy]] in 1992.
==Reception and legacy==
Megaw noted that "as he himself has said, although he has done his fair share of field work and excavation, his prime concern has been to produce works of synthesis and interpretation".{{sfn|Megaw|1976|p=9}} Megaw noted that Piggott viewed "archaeology as an oyster to be savoured whole and not simply to be subjected to the minutiae of macrofaunal and calorific analyses."{{sfn|Megaw|1976|p=9}} The historian [[Ronald Hutton]] stated that it was "one aspect of his greatness that he fostered the study of early modern antiquaries as an integral part of the self-awareness of his profession."{{sfn|Hutton|2005|p=382}}
In 1968 a number of Piggott's former pupils and colleagues assembled a collection of essays in dedication to him, titled ''Studies in Ancient Europe''.{{sfn|Megaw|1976|p=9}} In 1976 Megaw then published a second ''[[Festschrift]]'' which brought in consideration of Piggott's work on the archaeology of Asia and the Americas too.{{sfn|Megaw|1976|pp=9–10}}
==Publications==
Marjorie Robertson compiled a list of Piggott's books up to 1975 for his ''festschrift''.{{sfn|Robertson|1976|pp=320–331}}

Black (London) |- | 1944 | ''Some Ancient Cities of India'' | – | Oxford University Press (Bombay) |- | 1948 | ''Fire Among the Ruins'' | | Oxford University Press (London) |- | 1949 | ''British Prehistory'' | | Oxford University Press (London) |- | 1950 | ''Prehistoric India to 1000 BC'' | | Penguin (Harmondsworth) |- | 1950 | ''William Stukeley: An Eighteenth Century Antiquary'' | | Clarendon Press (Oxford) |- | 1951 | ''Cairnpapple Hill, West Lothian'' | | HMSO (Edinburgh) |- | 1951 | ''A Picture Book of Ancient British Art'' | Glyn Daniel | Cambridge University Press (Cambridge) |- | 1953 | ''William Camden and the Britannia'' | | Oxford University Press (London) |- | 1954 | ''The Neolithic Cultures of the British Isles'' | | Cambridge University Press (Cambridge) |- | 1958 | ''Inventaria Archaeologica GB 25-34: Early and Middle Bronze Age Grave-Groups and Hoards from Scotland'' (edited volume) | Margaret Stewart (editors) | Garraway (London) |- | 1958 | ''Scotland Before History'' | | Nelson (London) |- | 1959 | ''Approach to Archaeology'' | | A. and C. Black (London) |- | 1961 | ''The Dawn of Civilization'' (edited volume) | | Thames and Hudson (London) |- | 1962 | ''The Prehistoric Peoples of Scotland'' (edited volume) | | Routledge and Kegan Paul (London) |- | 1962 | ''The West Kennet Long Barrow: Excavations 1955–56'' | | HMSO (London) |- | 1963 | ''West Kennet Long Barrow: Wiltshire'' | | HMSO (London) |- | 1965 | ''Ancient Europe from the Beginnings of Agriculture to Classical Antiquity: A Survey'' | | Edinburgh University Press (Edinburgh) |- | 1965 | ''Prehistoric Societies'' | Grahame Clark | Hutchinson (London) |- | 1967 | ''Celts, Saxons and the Early Antiquaries'' | | Edinburgh University Press (Edinburgh) |- | 1968 | ''The Druids'' | | Thames and Hudson (London) |- | 1970 | ''Early Celtic Art'' | Derek Allen | Edinburgh University Press for the Arts Council of Great Britain (Edinburgh) |}
